content: General Electric (GE) helped pace outperformance by blue chip stocks as the Dow Jones industrial average gained more than 1% at one point, but then cut the gains to around 0.6% in late-afternoon trading on Thursday.X GE, up 1.1%, does not have the same impact on the Dow as it once did. At 14.70, even a future 1 point rally, equivalent to a gain of more than 6%, would not significantly hoist the Dow industrial higher by much.The Nasdaq composite lagged, losing early gains to fall 0.1%, as names such as digital TV hardware play Roku (ROKU), LendingTree (TREE) and waste control products play Stericycle (SRCL) all fell sharply, weighing on the tech-centered index.The S&P 500 was up 0.1%. At 2731, the large-cap gauge is trying to rally back above its 50-day moving average after a follow-through took place on Feb. 14. A follow-through is a bullish signal that confirms a new tradable market rally could be underway.The Innovator IBD 50 (FFTY) exchange-traded fund slumped nearly 0.7% lower. At 33, the collection of top-flight growth stocks is trading fractionally lower since Jan. 1. FFTY gained 37% in 2017.Winners led losers on the NYSE at one point by a comfortable 9-5 margin. On the Nasdaq, rising stocks virtually matched falling ones in number. But the Nasdaq is still the market leader since Jan. 1, up nearly 4.8% while the Dow industrials trail with a gain of less than 0.5%.At least six of the 30 components in the price-weighted Dow Jones industrials rose 2 points or more, including United Technologies (UTX). The industrial and manufacturing play burst back above the 10-week moving average near 132 in bullish fashion as shares rose more than 3% to 133.47 in volume running more than 50% above its 50-day average.United Tech, which makes aircraft engines, elevators and security systems, has been showing steady single-digit top and bottom line growth in most of the past seven quarters. But in 2018 and 2019, the Street expects earnings to accelerate, rising 6% to $7.05 a share this year and up 11% the next.United has risen 8% since rallying out of a five-month cup with handle at 123.38 in mid-December. At one point, before the intermediate-level correction flattened the market, United was up as much as 12.8%.Sign Up For Free IBD Newsletters: Market Prep | Tech ReportReturning to GE, one of the positive developments for the former market leader is the fact that Wall Street is encouraged by major reform plans by the new CEO John Flannery. Proof? The 2019 consensus earnings estimate has been revised higher, now seen at $1.06 a share, up 10% vs. an expected profit of 96 cents this year.This means GE is trading less than 14 times expected 2018 earnings; the Boston-based company recently slashed is quarterly cash dividend by half.  So with a 12-cent dividend per share, the annualized yield comes out to 3.3%, which hardly puts a dent into capital losses caused by the stock's 16.6% slide year to date.The S&P 500 trades roughly 20 times trailing 12-month earnings and shows an annualized dividend yield of 1.8%. (You can track the yield of the S&P 500 at the top of the General Market Indicators page, a PDF link at the bottom of the daily IBD Big Picture column.)The challenge, however, for GE, will be to find new avenues to boost the top line. Healthy sales, delivered by innovative new products and new markets, are the mother of strong earnings.GE is certainly in danger of falling out of the Dow due to its sharply hammered stock price. The stock is more than 52% below its 52-week high and trading well below the 50- and 200-day moving averages, a clear sign of weakness.Former Dow Jones industrial stocks such as Alcoa (AA), which has been split into two public companies including Arconic (ARNC), suffered such a fate in late 2013.At the time, the aluminum giant traded well below 10 a share. Computer and printer titan HP Inc. (HPQ), formerly Hewlett-Packard, and Bank of America (BAC) also departed the blue-chip Dow due to miserable stock performance.On IBD Stock Checkup,Elsewhere, the Dow Jones utility average rebounded 0.9%. But at 671, the interest rate-sensitive index is still down 7.3% since Jan. 1.The yield on the benchmark U.S. Treasury 10-year bond eased to 2.92%, signifying some bargain-hunting among fund managers, even as the U.S. dollar fell against both the euro and the yen. West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices rallied 1.6% to $62.66 a barrel.(Please follow Saito-Chung on Twitter at @IBD_DChung for more commentary on breakouts, top stocks, major indexes and financial markets.)RELATED:Where Is The Stock Market Headed? Read This Column Every DayThe Follow-Through Day Works: How It Sparked A Market Rally In December 1903When Did The Stock Market Follow-Through Take Place? What Should You Do Next?

Stocks took an early dive Thursday, after a volatile session in Japan rippled through to global markets.XThe Dow Jones industrial average opened down 0.4%, with Intel (INTC) and Caterpillar (CAT) posting the heaviest early losses. The S&P 500 slumped 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite tumbled 0.8%, with Stericycle (SRCL) and Ebay (EBAY) weighing on both indexes.In Japan, Tokyo's market flashed a possible warning signal, rising nearly 2% in morning trade, then crashing to a 1.7% loss before paring losses to 0.2% at the close. The Nikkei 225 had gained in 23 of 25 prior sessions and broke above the 23,000 level for the first time in 25 years just before the reversal.China's markets notched a positive session, with the Shanghai Composite up 0.4% Thursday and carrying a 1.7% gain so far for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index added 0.8%, up 1.9% for the week.Europe's markets traded sharply lower, as volatility in Tokyo compounded uncertainty tied to Brexit negotiations and U.S. political tax plans, topped off by corporate earnings. Frankfurt's DAX was down more than 1.1% in afternoon trade. The CAC-40 in Paris fell 0.9% and London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5%.Intel took the Dow's hardest early hit, down 1.1%, possibly due to news late Wednesday that Qualcomm (QCOM), which received an unsolicited $130 billion takeover bid this week from Broadcom (AVGO), was launching a chip aimed at competing with Intel in the market for server processing in cloud computing and data processing applications. Qualcomm shares traded down 1.1% at the open.Boeing (BA) rose 0.2%, buoyed by news of a $37 billion agreement to provide 300 single- and twin-aisle aircraft to China Aviation Suppliers, signed as part of President Trump's trade mission to Asia.On the Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500, beaten down shares of Stericycle pared losses to 8% in premarket trade, after the company's earnings and revenue missed analysts' third-quarter targets.Monster Beverage shed prem,arket losses and rose  0.6% at the starting bell.  Its third-quarter earnings met, and revenue slightly topped, consensus expectations. Gross margins decreased to 62.6% during the quarter, down from 63.8% a year ago. The move left the stock in a buy range above a 57.35 buy point in a flat base.Apple (AAPL) dropped 0.3% and all four FANG stocks traded lower ahead of the open. Netflix (NFLX) fell hardest, down 1.6%, possibly in response to Roku's third-quarter results.New issue Roku (ROKU) soared 38% in opening trade after a healthy first-time report as a publicly traded company. The gain left shares 14% below their September high, and 91% above their Sept. 28 IPO price.Generic drug maker Perrigo (PRGO) pounded out an early 12% advance. The Allegan, Mich.-based company reported a big beat on its third-quarter earnings line and its first earnings gain in seven quarters. Revenue slipped 2%, less than expected. The gain put shares in a buy range above two buy points: an early, alternative flat base entry at 89.29, and the base's standard buy point at 89.97.IBD 50 stock Alarm.com (ALRM) tumbled 15%, despite reporting a strong third-quarter performance and raised fourth-quarter revenue guidance. The loss sent shares diving below their 10-week moving average, and erased most of the stock's gain since clearing a flat base in August.Israel-based SolarEdge Technologies (SEDG) shot 14% higher out of the starting gate as third-quarter earnings and revenue, and fourth-quarter revenue guidance, topped analysts' views.  The stock is now up 29% since breaking out from a cup base in September.Sage Therapeutics (SAGE) scorched ahead 47% after announcing its post-partum depression treatment  brexanolone showed positive results in two late-stage clinical trials. The gap up gain sent shares to a new high, putting them in a buy range above a cup base buy point at 90.90.In economic news, first-time unemployment claims rose to 239,000 in the week ended Nov. 4, the Labor Department estimated. That was up from 229,000 claims in the prior week and above economist projections for 232,000 new applications.September wholesale inventories numbers from the Commerce Department are expected at 10 a.m. ET.RELATED:Nvidia Leads These 4 Top Earnings Reports Thursday: Investing Action Plan The Big Picture: Does This Gauge Point To Excessive Optimism?

Stocks launched higher at the starting bell Friday, boosted by a positive July payrolls report and earnings news that stirred a swarm of early stock moves.XThe Dow Jones industrial average jetted 0.2% higher at the open, looking to add a ninth day to the index's rally and turn the 22,000 mark into a level of support. JP Morgan (JPM) and Microsoft (MSFT) led the index in early trade.The S&P 500 also added 0.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite struggled just below that level, with Viacom (VIAB) and Stericycle (SRCL) weighing heavy on early trade.The Labor Department's July payrolls report showed jobs growth at 209,000 for the month, down from 231,000 new hires in June, but holding well above consensus expectations for a slump to 178,000 added employees. The closely watched unemployment rate ticked lower, to 4.3% from 4.4%, in line with expectations. Manufacturing payrolls swelled by 16,000, far above estimates for a 3,000-job increase.The Commerce Department reported the trade deficit tightened in June to $43.6 billion, down May's $46.4 billion gap and below consensus views for a narrowing to $44.4 billion.Baker Hughes (BHGE) delivers its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m. ET.On the Dow, JPMorgan vaulted to the front of the index with a 1.2% gain. Walt Disney (DIS) took the Dow's hardest opening hit, down more than 1%.

Apple rose 0.5%, and the four FANG stocks all traded higher. Facebook (FB) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) ran at the head of the class, each with 0.6% gains.On the earnings front, GoPro (GPRO) spiked 17% in opening action. The action camera maker turned in a hefty second-quarter beat and an increase in third-quarter revenue guidance after Thursday's close. Longbow Research upgraded GoPro to neutral from underperform Friday. The move returned shares to well above their 40-week moving average for the first time since November, starting the right side of a 10-month consolidation.Yelp (YELP) screamed 26% higher after topping analysts' second-quarter expectations, meeting views for third-quarter guidance, and agreeing to sell its Eat24 business to Grubhub (GRUB). The stock also returned to support above its 40-week moving average, breaking out past a double-bottom buy point of 36.35.Weight Watchers (WTW) packed on a 22% premarket gain after its second-quarter sales and earnings trounced analyst estimates. The gap up gain left shares extended above the stock's first rebound from support at its 10-week moving average since clearing a seven-week cup base in April.IBD 50 stock Arista Networks (ANET) powered up 21% on a powerful second-quarter performance and third-quarter guidance. Arista's move cleared two alternate flat-base buy points at 159.10 and 163.07. The gap up move created an extended buying range opportunity, ranging to 175.98.Early stock moves were even more enthusiastic to the downside.Applied OptoElectronics (AAOI) cratered 28%, despite a hefty second-quarter earnings beat. Chipmaker Impinj (PI) swooned 20%. Natural Grocers Vitamin Cottage (NGVC) toppled 23%.MercadoLibre (MELI) dropped 9% after reporting mixed second-quarter results. The loss sent shares below their 10-week moving average in heavy trade, marking a sell signal.RELATED: Do Diverging Stock Indexes Signal Trouble? Grubhub, Yelp Join Forces As Earnings Reports Beat ViewsApplied Optoelectronics Plunges On Weak Guidance; Opticals HitThe Big Number For Stocks In Friday's Jobs Report Isn't JobsAcacia Communications September Quarter Guidance Light, Stock SlipsHere's Why Optical Stocks Are Selling Off Today

Stocks traded lower soon after Friday's opening bell, with earnings reports and disappointing second-quarter GDP estimates factoring into early trade.The Dow industrials fell 0.4% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq dropped 0.2%.The economy grew 1.2% in the second quarter, according to an initial GDP estimate from the Commerce Department, effectively level with the first quarter's 1.1% gain and far below expectations for a 2.6% increase. Prices, on the other hand, jumped more than expected -- up 2.2% vs. a  0.4% increase in the first quarter and above views for a 1.8% gain.Labor costs were in line with expectations, with the Labor Department's Employment Cost Index up 0.6% during the second quarter.An update on July Midwest manufacturing from Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index is up next at 9:45 a.m. ET, followed by the University of Michigan's July Consumer Sentiment Index at 10 a.m.San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams speaks at 9:30 a.m. ET.  Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan speaks at 1 p.m.Techs were on the move ahead of Friday's open, with Alphabet (GOOGL) and Amazon.com (AMZN) pacing the pack after strong quarterly reports late Thursday.Google parent Alphabet rose 3.7% in morning trade as its second-quarter earnings bounced back from a first-quarter miss, topping analysts' expectations.Amazon climbed less than 1% after handily clearing analysts' second-quarter targets and giving generally healthy guidance, but gains were moderated somewhat by weaker-than-expected third-quarter operating income guidance. One of IBD's Leaderboard stocks, Amazon ended Thursday's session just off its July 12 high and extended after a June rebound from its 10-week moving average.IBD 50 stock Gigamon (GIMO) swung up 4% after a nice beat on its Q2 results. The network security firm's stock is extended above a 34.24 cup-with-handle buy point.Beyond tech stocks, Rubbermaid products maker Newell Brands (NWL) climbed 7% on stronger-than-forecast second-quarter earnings and revenue. The report marked Newell's first quarter since its $15.4 billion acquisition of Jarden in April.Stamps.com (STMP) was an early winner, but reversed to trade down nearly 8%.Railcar manufacturing and leasing operation Trinity Industries (TRN) surged 6.5% after its quarterly results.On the downside, Expedia (EXPE) dropped 3% after a mixed second-quarter report. Expedia is considering spinning off its majority stake in Trivago, a unit that brought in $201 million in second-quarter sales, up 41% vs. the year-earlier period.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dived 7.5%, despite stronger-than-forecast Q2 revenue and earnings. The company said it had received far fewer table permits than requested for its new $4.2 billion casino in Macau, China.Other earnings-related losses included a 18% plunge for Stericycle (SRCL), Western Digital (WDC) falling 9%, and Baidu (BIDU) down 5%.Oil prices were under some early pressure, with West Texas Intermediate down a fraction and near $41 a barrel, and Brent crude off more than 1% and just above $42. Gold ticked up 1% to above $1,344 an ounce. The dollar moved broadly lower, and the 10-year Treasury yield reversed, slipping 2 basis points to 1.49%.In the other global markets, China's leading indexes slipped on Friday, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 bumped up 0.6% after the Bank of Japan voted for a mild increase in its monetary stimulus measures. Europe's markets were mixed, with up and down gaps widening in afternoon trade.As the stock market heads into the final trading session of July, tech stocks and small caps have been the month's clear leaders. The Nasdaq climbed 6.5% for the month through Thursday, giving the index a 2.9% year-to-date gain. The S&P 500's July gain was 3.4% through Thursday, its fifth straight monthly advance, putting it 6.2% above its Dec. 31 close.Blue chips lagged the market, with the Dow industrials up 2.9%. Among the small-cap gauges, the Russell 2000 showed a 5.7% gain through Thursday and the S&P Smallcap 600 advanced 4.9%, rising to new highs mid-month, then holding its ground.

Stocks backed out of mixed trade into increasing losses early Friday, as weak economic news and earnings reports placed pressure on the morning's trade.The Dow and the S&P 500 dropped 0.5% apiece, while the Nasdaq slipped 0.6%. Small caps fell at a slightly faster pace, with the Russell 2000 showing a 0.8% decline.  Volume rose in the stock market today, gaining 3% on the NYSE and 7% on the Nasdaq, vs. trade at the same time Thursday.Economic news opened with below-forecast growth in personal spending and prices for March, although personal income outpaced projections. Midwest manufacturing slowed, with Kingsbury International reporting its April Chicago purchasing managers index at 50.4 for the month, down from 53.6 in March and far weaker than the 53.4 tally expected by analysts.Consumer views also dimmed in April, according to the University of Michigan, which put its Consumer Sentiment Index at 89 for the month — below March's 89.7 and disappointing forecasts for an increase to 90.4.More than 25 of the 30 Dow stocks moved lower at the open. Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Intel (INTC) were the only two to drop more than 1%. Exxon Mobil (XOM) led, rising 1% after reporting mixed first quarter results.Tech stocks soaring after quarterly reports were the market's focal point in early trade: Amazon.com (AMZN) soared 10%, Expedia (EXPE) leapt 9% and LinkedIn (LNKD) advanced 6%.Get detailed chart analysis on Amazon.com by subscribing to IBD's Leaderboard feature. Oil and energy stocks were pounding out strong gains, holding many of the top slots in the S&P 500, as oil prices advanced almost 1% ahead of the weekly rig count report from Baker Hughes (BHI), due out at 1 p.m.ET.But earnings news also energized broader segments of the market.Housewares leader Newell Brands (NWL) gapped up to a 7% gain after its first quarter revenue and earnings topped projections, and management lifted its Q2 guidance above consensus views. The heavy volume gain hoisted shares above a 45.67 buy point in a first stage cup-with-handle base.Among pharmaceutical stocks, Ireland's Shire (SHPG) popped 4% in powerful volume after a a strong Q1 report. The stock is working on its sixth straight weekly advance. Gilead Sciences (GILD) dived 5% as both its earnings and revenue missed first quarter expectations.  The loss put shares down nearly 10% for the week, killing an attempt to build the right side of a six-month consolidation.Medical waste collection specialist Stericycle (SRCL) crumbled to a 20% loss. As an analyst downgrade followed Thursday's Q1 earnings miss. The loss set the stock back to 2013 levels.Hard drive makers Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technologies (STX) posted deep declines after reporting their fiscal Q3 results.Seagate unraveled 15% as earnings fell far short of consensus projections and revenue just met previously lowered guidance. S&P Global maintained its hold rating on the stock and lowered its price target to 29, from 31.Western dropped 10% as both earnings and revenue stopped short of analyst projections. Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock to neutral from outperform and lowered its price target to 50, from 55.Among IBD 50 stocks, nearly all of the list moved lower at the start of trade.  Stamps.com (STMP) was among the few exceptions, rising 2% in strong trade, taking back a small piece of Thursday's 12% tumble.On the downside, Ellie Mae (ELLI) pared an initial 12% dive to 8% ,after what appeared to be a solid Q1 report. Earnings and revenue topped analyst consensus views. Management gave an upbeat view of company performance and outlook, and raised guidance above projections.  Stephens & Co. downgraded the stock to equal weight, from overweight, following the report. The loss put Ellie's shares below their 50-day moving average in very heavy trade.

Tech stocks led a broad early rally Friday, as earnings surprises and foreign stimulus news buoyed global markets. The Nasdaq bolted ahead 2%. The S&P 500 climbed 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.8% gain.
Volume was mixed, rising 32% on the Nasdaq and dipping a fraction lower on the NYSE, in relation to trade at the same time Thursday.
While much of the week has been focused on company news and quarterly reports, the stock market today tapped into a wide range of influences.

The European Central Bank's news Thursday that it would consider additional stimulus measures in December launched a rally on global markets. China's central bank trimmed interest rates and announced a swathe of banking policy changes. U.S. markets received a psychological lift as both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 punched decisively through resistance at their respective 200-day moving averages.

Another boost came from researcher Markit, whose preliminary manufacturing purchasing managers' index for October rose to 54, up from 53 in September and better than consensus views for a no-change reading.

Oil prices are worth watching, as West Texas Intermediate gave up early gains to trade 2% lower, below $45 a barrel, ahead of Baker-Hughes' weekly rig count report, due out at 1 p.m. ET. Oil is trading down more than 6% on the week, following a surprise surge in weekly inventories.
On top of all that, a raft of high-profile earnings wins sent some of the biggest tech names soaring in early trade.

Alphabet (GOOG) and Microsoft (MSFT) led the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, up 11% and 10%, respectively after reporting third quarter surprises. The strong-volume gain lifted Alphabet nearly 6% past a 678.74 buy point in a 13-week cup base.
Amazon.com (AMZN) soared out of buying range, up 7% in heavy trade after reporting a surprise profit late Thursday.
Other notable gains included Ireland-based drugmaker Mallinckrodt (MNK), up 7%, and Verisign (VRSN) also leaping 7% to take a new high in strong trade after a strong Q3 report late Thursday.

Among leaders, more than 30% of the IBD 50 list stocks rose more than 1%. At the top of the list, Hawaiian Holdings (HA) surfed up 4% to snatch another new high in strong trade. The parent of Hawaiian Airlines has gained in 12 of the past 13 sessions and is extended after an early October breakout.
Noah Holdings (NOAH) gapped up to a 4% gain in heavy trade. The stock is trying to climb the right side of a deep consolidation.
At the bottom of the list, Foot Locker (FL) tumbled 6% in big trade, possibly stumbling in a sympathy moved linked to Skechers (SKX).
The session also provided some breathtaking losses.
Skechers dived 32% and Pandora (P) tanked 34% after broad earnings misses. Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) dropped 9%. VF Corp (VFC) tumbled 8%.

Stericycle (SRCL) folded 23% as Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock, to neutral from outperform, and lowered its price target to 130 from 145 after a weak Q3 report late Thursday. The drop sent the medical-waste-collection services provider below its 10-week line of support and deep below a 148.96 buy point.Tech stocks led a broad early rally Friday, as earnings surprises and foreign stimulus news buoyed global markets. The major stock indexes closed with losses of more than 1% Wednesday after the indexes made bearish price reversals.
The Nasdaq, which had been up about 1% earlier, closed nearly 1.2% lower. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average slid about 1.4%.
Volume rose across the board, early indications showed. Declining stocks led advancers by more than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq and by 11-to-4 on the NYSE.
The way the indexes reversed course Wednesday quickly dampened the bullish tone of the prior session, when the main indexes made a follow-through rally confirmation.
The number of stocks rising in big volume rapidly diminished in the final two hours of trading.

Apple (AAPL) was a highlight in the stock market today after the company unveiled a series of new products. It introduced the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, a larger tablet dubbed the iPad Pro, major improvements to its Apple TV franchise and other product upgrades.

But Apple shares fell 2%. Suppliers of components for Apple products were weaker, too. ARM Holdings (ARMH) fell 3%, Avago Technologies (AVGO) nearly 2%, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) more than 1%, Qorvo (QRVO) 3%, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) 1%.

MasterCard (MA) dropped 3%, sinking back to its 200-day moving average, after the credit-card company warned that profit growth would slow in the next few years. The stock has been below the 50-day moving average for a couple of weeks already.

Stericlycle (SRCL) tumbled 6%, dropping to its 50-day moving average, where it now looks for support. The stock closed 5% below the 143.79 buy point of flat base. The medical-waste handling company announced an offering of 7 million depositary shares that represent 10% of certain preferred stock.

WCI Communities (WCIC) went right back below its 25.74 buy point. The homebuilders' industry group was broadly lower Wednesday, and WCI led with a 6% loss in heavy trading.The major stock indexes closed with losses of more than 1% Wednesday after the indexes made bearish price reversals.The Nasdaq, which had been up about 1% earlier, closed nearly 1.2% lower. A choppy June gouged many ETF investment portfolios. But investors in low volatility strategies fared relatively better amid tough Greek debt negotiations, a China sell-off and, closer to home, an uncertain rate outlook.
In the past year, "plain vanilla" cap-weighted ETF strategies outperformed in a market that's still in an overall uptrend. Recent results may offer a lesson for ETF investors.

"It reinforced that different factors do well across various market cycles," says Aniket Ullal of First Bridge Data, an analytics firm. "Despite the excitement around smart beta strategies, often traditional market-cap weightings can win."

PowerShares S&P 500 Low Volatility (SPLV), a $4.75 billion exchange traded fund, gave up 1.7% last month. Other ETFs investing in large-cap domestic equities fared worse. SDPR S&P 500  (SPY) shrank 2%, Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP) 2.3% and WisdomTree LargeCap Dividend (DLN) 2.5%.
A longer-term view paints a different picture. SPLV rose 5.5% in the year ended June 30. SPY gained 7.2% in that period.

A smart beta ETF, SPLV invests in 100 stocks in the S&P 500 with the lowest volatility in the prior 12 months. Holdings include insurer Chubb (CB), waste expert Stericycle (SRCL) and drug chain CVS (CVS).
When things fall apart, low volatility ETFs shine. According to Ullal, they can add value to portfolios by minimizing large drawdowns during market downturns. (They tend to lag in uptrends.)
In a study that looked across market cycles, he found the S&P 500 Low Volatility Index's 85% gain beat 41% for the S&P 500 index over an 11-year period ended May 2013.

"This is because on the days when the S&P 500 declined, those declines were very substantial," he wrote in his report. "This illustrates very clearly the difficulty of clawing back from a drawdown in one's portfolio."

While low volatility indexes have been around for a while, ETFs tracking these products are relatively new. SPLV and iShares MSCI USA Minimum Volatility (USMV) debuted in 2011, right around the time the stock market last saw a 10% correction. So they're in a sense untested in the real world.
"We haven't seen them have a chance to shine," says Todd Rosenbluth, director of ETF research at S&P Capital IQ. But that time could be coming.
"Historically, the stock market declines in value heading into the Fed increasing interest rates," said Rosenbluth. "The time is right for investors to at least be considering low volatility ETFs."
He suggests SPLV could be combined with an ETF such as SPY, "if you wanted to have S&P 500 exposure but reduce risk for a while."
Low volatility ETFs have their own risks. They include major sector bets resulting from the alternative indexing style.

"The exposures are going to shift," Rosenbluth said. "It requires an investor to look at them on a regular basis."A choppy June gouged many ETF investment portfolios. But investors in low volatility strategies fared relatively better amid tough Greek debt negotiations, a China sell-off and, closer to home, an uncertain rate outlook.In the past year, "plain vanilla" cap-weighted ETF strategies outperformed in a market that's still in an overall uptrend. Recent results may offer a lesson for ETF investors."It reinforced that different factors do well across various market cycles," says Aniket Ullal of First Bridge Data, an analytics firm. "Despite the excitement around smart beta strategies, often traditional market-cap weightings can win."PowerShares S&P 500 Low Volatility (SPLV), a $4.75 billion exchange traded fund, gave up 1.7% last month. Other ETFs investing in large-cap domestic equities fared worse. SDPR S&P 500  (SPY) shrank 2%, Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP) 2.3% and WisdomTree LargeCap Dividend (DLN) 2.5%.A longer-term view paints a different picture. SPLV rose 5.5% in the year ended June 30. SPY gained 7.2% in that period.A smart beta ETF, SPLV invests in 100 stocks in the S&P 500 with the lowest volatility in the prior 12 months. Holdings include insurer Chubb (CB), waste expert Stericycle (SRCL) and drug chain CVS (CVS).When things fall apart, low volatility ETFs shine. According to Ullal, they can add value to portfolios by minimizing large drawdowns during market downturns. (They tend to lag in uptrends.)In a study that looked across market cycles, he found the S&P 500 Low Volatility Index's 85% gain beat 41% for the S&P 500 index over an 11-year period ended May 2013."This is because on the days when the S&P 500 declined, those declines were very substantial," he wrote in his report. "This illustrates very clearly the difficulty of clawing back from a drawdown in one's portfolio."While low volatility indexes have been around for a while, ETFs tracking these products are relatively new. SPLV and iShares MSCI USA Minimum Volatility (USMV) debuted in 2011, right around the time the stock market last saw a 10% correction. So they're in a sense untested in the real world."We haven't seen them have a chance to shine," says Todd Rosenbluth, director of ETF research at S&P Capital IQ. But that time could be coming."Historically, the stock market declines in value heading into the Fed increasing interest rates," said Rosenbluth. "The time is right for investors to at least be considering low volatility ETFs."He suggests SPLV could be combined with an ETF such as SPY, "if you wanted to have S&P 500 exposure but reduce risk for a while."Low volatility ETFs have their own risks. They include major sector bets resulting from the alternative indexing style."The exposures are going to shift," Rosenbluth said. "It requires an investor to look at them on a regular basis."

ETFs that track the iconic S&P 500 index can produce very different results. They may approach that benchmark's investment universe from distinct angles. Most give investors plain-vanilla broad exposure to the U.S. stock market.
Others offer less volatility than a traditional stock portfolio. Or they overweight stocks that outperform in certain market conditions.
These three S&P 500 exchange traded funds exemplify those differences:

For most ETF investors, the mighty $174.28 billion SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) represents both the broad market and the benchmark against which they compare the performance of other investments. SPY has a simple goal — diversified, efficient exposure to roughly 500 U.S. large-cap and some midcap stocks.
A market-cap-weighted ETF, it gives a bigger weighting to larger stocks. Big price changes in these holdings can have a dramatic impact on the value of a cap-weighted ETF.

Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) are its top three holdings, weighing in at about 4% for Apple and 2% for the other two. More recent additions include IBD Leaderboard stocks Mallinckrodt (MNK), Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS).
SPY has a 0.09% expense ratio, or $9 in fees for every $10,000 invested. It's up 3% in 2015 and produced an average annual gain of 20.4% in the past three years.

The $11.41 billion Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP) owns all the stocks in the S&P 500, but gives greater weight to smaller stocks. A smart beta ETF, it follows an equal-weighted index. This method gives each stock more or less the same portfolio weighting. Apple, with a market cap of $742.5 billion, gets a 0.2% stake in RSP. So does IBD 50 stock United Health Services (UHS), whose market cap is $12.6 billion.
In SPY, United Health has a 0.06% weight.
RSP has a 0.4% expense ratio. It has gained 2% year to date and averaged an annual 22.5% advance in the past three years.

Its returns also beat SPY's in the past five- and 10-year periods. Its stock market gains were helped in part by the skew towards smaller stocks in the underlying index. These companies tend to outperform when the market's in a strong uptrend.

PowerShares S&P Low Volatility (SPLV) is also a smart beta ETF. It selects the 100 S&P 500 stocks with the lowest volatility and gives bigger weightings to those that are less volatile. But those differences are relatively small.
Stericycle (SRCL), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Allstate (ALL) are its top three holdings. They get a 1.2% portfolio weighting. The stocks with the smallest weightings get 0.9%.
SPLV has a 0.25% expense ratio. Low volatility ETFs can lag in bull markets. SPLV has fallen 1.4% in 2015 and gained an average 15.3% in the past three years.
But this low-vol ETF should hold up better than its S&P 500 peers if the market trends down and in the long term, experts say. It does not have a five-year return history.
It's important to understand what's inside an exchange traded fund to find the best fit for your successful investing needs.

Pall (PLL) shares shot up to an all-time high in strong volume Tuesday after its fiscal first-quarter earnings growth surged above estimates.

The maker of filtration and purification systems for life sciences and industry said earnings for the quarter rose 28% to 89 cents per share, beating forecasts by 8 cents. Revenue climbed nearly 11% to $696.5 million, vs. Wall Street's forecast of $684 million.
Shares were up 2.8% on the stock market today.
In life sciences, an 18% rise in biopharmaceutical sales, partly due to recent acquisitions, added to a 4% gain in food and beverages and offset a 2% drop in medical market products.
In the industrial market, sales in process technologies climbed 19%, while revenue for the aerospace and microelectronics sectors grew in single digits.

"The dramatic strengthening of the U.S. dollar, which began during our (fiscal) first quarter, will be a very significant earnings headwind for the year," CEO Larry Kingsley said. "However, our operating momentum provides us with confidence that we can largely offset (foreign exchange) and deliver a full-year outlook consistent with our original guidance."
The company affirmed its EPS guidance for fiscal 2015, which began Nov. 1, of $3.75 to $3.95, with the midpoint just below consensus forecasts of $3.88.
Stericycle (SRCL), which provides waste management services to hospitals, was down fractionally.
Elsewhere in the group, Clarcor (CLC) was up less than 1%, Ceco Environmental (CECE) slid 4%, and Donaldson (DCI) dipped fractionally.

While buyouts certainly have helped Stericycle (SRCL) become larger, the medical waste handler also pursues other growth strategies.
Analysts especially like its push to add complementary services.
These offerings include Steri-Safe, which helps smaller customers comply with rules from OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

Plus, Stericycle helps drugmakers with recalls and the disposal of pharmaceutical waste like pills and liquids. And it offers sharps management, saying this service reduces the risk of needle sticks for doctors, nurses and technicians.
All of these offerings are complements to Stericycle's core business of hauling away and disposing of medical waste, says CFO Frank ten Brink.
"These are very powerful opportunities for us to grow the business," ten Brink said.

He says Steri-Safe can "more than double the revenue" with a small customer, if that client is currently only using one Stericycle service. "Sharps management and pharmawaste can more than triple the relationship with a large customer," ten Brink adds.
The CFO says the complementary services strategy is working for a simple reason: "It centers around customer needs."
For example, many smaller customers just aren't experts on OSHA standards. These clients are often doctors or dentists without a huge staff.
"Many physicians have never really in school been educated on how to comply with OSHA," ten Brink told IBD. "They're great doctors, but ... there are lots of rules that are out there."
Meanwhile, the focus on pharmaceutical waste comes as regulators are increasingly worried about residual drugs in the water supply. Some states have passed "no-flush" laws.
The complementary services strategy also works because it targets existing customers.

"If we already handle your medical waste, hopefully we've built a good relationship with you," ten Brink said. "It's never easy to sell any additional services, but it's easier if you already have a relationship with a customer."
The Lake Forest, Ill., company sees lots of room for growth within complementary services.
Less than 20% of its so-called "large-quantity customers," such as major hospitals, are using multiple services. That leaves a big base available for possible expansion.
Among small-quantity customers, which can range from school-nurse stations to tattoo parlors, just one-third currently use multiple services.
Stericycle, the nation's largest handler of medical waste, developed Steri-Safe and the pharmaceutical waste offerings internally, ten Brink says.
It got into sharps management and handling recalls with acquisitions, but then built on those offerings.

"We have done it both ways," the CFO said. "We're not afraid to get into new things, and that can either be done by developing it internally or through acquiring know-how."While buyouts certainly have helped Stericycle (SRCL) become larger, the medical waste handler also pursues other growth strategies.Analysts especially like its push to add complementary services.These offerings include Steri-Safe, which helps smaller customers comply with rules from OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.Plus, Stericycle helps drugmakers with recalls and the disposal of pharmaceutical waste like pills and liquids. Medical-waste services might not show the kind of fast growth of certain high-tech fields. But the highly regulated business is a steady eddy grower that plows through good times and bad with equal aplomb. Stericycle (SRCL), the largest provider of medical waste services in the U.S., is a case in point. It breezed through the recession with mid- to high-single-digit…
Last fall, $1.2 billion MFS Mid Cap Growth Fund was willing to buy growth stocks with a little cyclicality.
That play is done. Now the fund is aiming for pure-play growth stocks.
"Back then, some of those names were on sale," co-manager Paul Gordon said Monday. "If you were willing to take some cyclical risk, you could get stocks cheaper."
"But that's played out now," Gordon added. "We're not early in the cycle. Margins have recovered. Valuations are up. So we're even more focused on just secular, three-plus-years earnings stories."

Ecolab (ECL) is an example of the fund's shift. The fund opened a stake in February. The stock was trading in the low to mid-70s. The cleaning products supplier's earnings per share have accelerated for three quarters.

"We look at it as a sustainable market-share gainer," Gordon said. "The stock had underperformed but earnings were growing above the market pace. So the stock was cheaper as cyclical names were getting more expensive."
Around the same time, the fund trimmed Cummins (CMI), whose valuation was looking pricey, he says.
The fund added to its stake in Stericycle (SRCL) in February. The medical-waste collector was trading around the mid-90s. Now it's above 105.
"Regardless of what the economy is doing, there is medical waste in the U.S. and abroad," Gordon said. "These guys pick it up. So their earnings and revenues are not cyclical."
Riding The Rails
The fund modestly added to its stake in Kansas City Southern (KSU) in December.
"These guys have a number of growth drivers," Gordon said. He cited growth of manufacturing in the U.S., transportation of crude oil and grain and an expected increase in transporting new cars.
"And if you look a couple years out, they should get business from plastics and ethylene factories being built in the U.S. as a result of low natural gas prices," he said.
The stock is up 42% over the past 12 months. It's tested its 10-week moving average line twice this month and hasn't been below the line since November.
Among other holdings, Gordon says FleetCor Technologies (FLT) has benefited from acquisitions.
"It buys poorly managed businesses that have big profit opportunities once FleetCor starts to manage them, often in faster growing international markets," Gordon said.
The provider and processor of payment cards for commercial vehicle fleets often does a better job of controlling costs and raising prices than its takeovers did for themselves, he adds.
The stock has eased 4% from its recent high, but remains above its 10-week moving average.
Chuy's Holdings (CHUY) debuted in July at 13. The Tex-Mex chain offers full-service dining. With bills averaging about $13 per customer vs. $16.50 for competitors, it attracts customers, Gordon says.
"They have a lot of unit growth potential," Gordon said. "They should grow units at about a 20% annual clip."
The fund was up 7.67% this year going into Tuesday. Its midcap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. averaged a 7.18% gain. The big-cap S&P 500 was up 9.51%.

Over the past three years Mid Cap Growth's average annual return was 10.14% vs. 9.63% for its peers and 10.96% for the S&P 500.Last fall, $1.2 billion MFS Mid Cap Growth Fund was willing to buy growth stocks with a little cyclicality.That play is done. Stocks pulled back from their intraday highs Friday in midday action. The Nasdaq clung to a 0.2% gain after being up as much as 0.9%. The S&P 500 rose 0.6% and the NYSE composite added 0.8%. The defensive Dow Jones Utility Average held a 1.1% gain. Volume was up sharply across the board. Today is a quadruple witching day, which…

The stock indexes posted gains in midday action Friday but were trading well off session highs.The market got a boost from a cease-fire in Libya and news that there was an international effort to knock down the yen. A weak yen would help Japan's export-driven economy.The NYSE composite advanced 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Nasdaq 0.4%. The small-cap S&P 600 was up 1%, but the Philadelphia semiconductor index rose just 0.1%.Volume was up sharply because of quadruple witching: the expiration of contracts for stock index futures, stock index options, stock options and single stock futures options. This usually leads to greater volume and increased volatility.Many top-rated stocks were riding the witching-volume wave. More than half of the stocks in the IBD 50 were showing volume at least 40% greater than usual. But among those fast traders, slightly more than half were down.Polypore International (PPO), which is in the specialty chemicals industry group, gapped down 5% in volume that was tracking about eight times above average. The company priced a previously announced public offering of 4.5 million shares. The sell price was set at 52.75. The stock closed at 55.69 Thursday.Cloud-computing play and former leader F5 Networks (FFIV) slid 3% in triple volume. The stock closed below its 200-day moving average Thursday and is burrowing further beneath the line.On the upside, medical waste handler Stericycle (SRCL) popped 2% in almost triple its usual trade. The stock has formed a base-on-base pattern. The Lake Forest, Ill., company is known for its steady earnings history. The five-year earnings Stability Factor is 2 on a scale that runs from a calm 1 to a wild 99.Medical stock ViroPharma (VPHM) surged 4% in more than double its routine volume. The stock broke out of a base March 9, clearing an 18.80 buy point.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, tobacco and gold miners were among the best gainers. Apparel and retail groups were struggling.
The major indexes closed near session highs for the second day in a row. They fell in morning trading after a mixed jobs report but then rallied into the close.

The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 rose 0.6% and 0.3%, respectively. The NYSE composite ended fractionally lower. Turnover increased from Thursday's level on the Nasdaq but fell on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.
Among the top-rated stocks breaking out Friday were sports clothing retailer Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and medical waste manager Stericycle (SRCL).

Lululemon jumped 7% in strong trade as the stock cleared a flat base and reached a new all-time high. The possible buy points for this base are 74.70 and 73.83. In each case, Lululemon remains in a potential buying zone, since it finished less than 5% past either buy point. The stock has earned an IBD Composite Rating of 97, not far from the best-possible grade of 99.

Stericycle surged 6% in big volume, topping an 82.31 buy point from a square-box base. The company said late Thursday that its adjusted Q4 EPS increased 25% to 69 cents, above estimates. Sales grew 25% to $393.5 million, also ahead of forecasts. Stericycle got an additional lift Friday as Wedbush upgraded the stock to outperform from neutral. The stock climbed as much as 11% on Friday before giving up some gains to finish 2% beyond its 82.31 buy point.

Friday's top-performing groups included jewelry companies, clothing manufacturers and fiber-optics firms, which were led by JDS Uniphase's (JDSU) 27% pop after its strong earnings report late Thursday. The session's worst-performing groups were solar stocks, oilfield services companies and RV makers.
In jobs news, the Labor Department said 36,000 new jobs were created in January, missing views. On the plus side, the unemployment rate fell to 9% last month, down from 9.4% in December.

The top-rated companies slated to report earnings Monday include Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), which plans to issue its report before the bell. Monday's economic news will include a consumer credit report from the Federal Reserve.

On the plus side, the unemployment rate fell to 9% last month, down from 9.4% in December.The top-rated companies slated to report earnings Monday include Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), which plans to issue its report before the bell. Monday's economic news will include a consumer credit report from the Federal Reserve.

The major indexes showed some pluck Thursday, as they closed with modest gains after spending most of the day in negative territory. The market appeared to shrug off news of increasing violence in Egypt that in the morning had overshadowed some encouraging U.S. economic reports.

The major indexes showed some pluck Thursday, as they closed with modest gains after spending most of the day in negative territory. The market appeared to shrug off news of increasing violence in Egypt that in the morning had overshadowed some encouraging U.S. economic reports.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!
The Nasdaq composite, NYSE composite and S&P 500 all finished up 0.2%. Volume fell from Wednesday's levels on the Nasdaq, but rose on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Retail stocks fared well, helped by chains reporting strong same-store sales for January. Among top-rated retailers, Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) gained 6% in strong turnover. The specialty retailer has bounced off its 10-week moving average after clearing a 37.34 square-box buy point on Jan. 6. Ulta finished just 2% past the high of 38.25 that it hit just before its pullback, meaning it remains in a possible buying range.

After hours, JDS Uniphase (JDSU) surged as it posted adjusted Q2 EPS of 29 cents, crushing views. The stock, which boasts a 97 IBD Composite Rating, is well extended from its last proper buy point of 13.10. One new driver for the company is its role as a parts supplier for sensor technology used in Microsoft's (MSFT) Kinect motion-gaming system.

Stericycle (SRCL) also gained as it reported earnings after the bell. The medical-waste handler achieved adjusted EPS of 69 cents, beating views. The stock was trading up in thin after-hours action after gaining 1% in the regular session. Stericycle has been consolidating along its 10-week line.

On the downside, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) fell as much as 6% in extended-hours trading in the wake of a quarterly earnings reports issued after the bell. The casino operator posted Q4 EPS of 42 cents, above views. But revenue came in at $2.02 billion, missing expectations. In the regular session, the stock had gained 2% in above-average trade. Sands has been working on a new base since November.
Weekly initial jobless claims fell by 42,000 last week to 415,000, below the consensus estimate of 422,000, while Q4 U.S. productivity grew 2.6%, also beating views.
On Friday, the Labor Department will release its job numbers for January. Health insurer Aetna (AET) is also expected to report its quarterly earnings.

The major indexes picked up steam in late-morning action Wednesday, buoyed by encouraging signs for the U.S. economy.
The Nasdaq gained 1.5%, the NYSE composite 1.4%, S&P 500 1.4% and the Dow 1.2%. Volume was tracking lower across the board compared with the same period Tuesday.
Speaking in front of the House Budget Committee, Bernanke said he expects the U.S. economic recovery to remain intact, despite problems in Europe, high unemployment and a shaky housing market.
Meanwhile, wholesale inventories rose 0.4% in April, slightly below estimates of 0.5%. Sales climbed 0.7%, topping views of 0.6%.
Skechers (SKX) advanced 6% in rapid turnover. The shoe retailer is trading beneath its 50-day moving average, but maintains a strong 97 Relative Price Strength Rating.
Ross Stores (ROST) rose 3.5% in more than twice its normal trade. The discount apparel retailer's stock rebounded above its 50-day line and now sits just 4% off its 52-week high.

Stericycle (SRCL) gained 3% in heavy volume. The medical waste disposal firm's stock marched to a 52-week peak.The major indexes picked up steam in late-morning action Wednesday, buoyed by encouraging signs for the U.S. economy.The Nasdaq gained 1.5%, the NYSE composite 1.4%, S&P 500 1.4% and the Dow 1.2%. The major indexes rose for most of the afternoon to finish with solid gains and near their session highs.

The Nasdaq composite tacked on 0.8%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 both advanced 0.6%. All three indexes hit new multi-year highs for the second day in a row. Volume decreased modestly from Tuesday's level on the Nasdaq, but increased slightly on the NYSE, early data showed.

After hours, Open Text (OTEX) was volatile after the maker of content-management software reported Q3 EPS that missed forecasts, but Q3 revenue beat expectations. The stock initially fell in late trade, then moved into positive territory. Open Text, No. 20 in this week's IBD 50, rose 1% during the regular session. Earlier this month, the stock bounced off its 10-week moving average — its first rebound since clearing a 59.58 flat-base buy point.

Also after the closing bell, Starbucks (SBUX) fell as its 2011 EPS target came in below views. The coffee giant reported Q2 EPS that matched forecasts, along with Q2 revenue that topped expectations. Starbucks, part of this week's IBD Big Cap 20, has been working on a possible flat base and finding support at its 10-week line.

On the upside, Stericycle (SRCL) eased in late trading as it reported Q1 EPS and sales that surpassed estimates. The medical waste handler, No. 45 in this week's IBD 50, is extended after clearing a square-box base in February and then bouncing off its 10-week line.
Baidu (BIDU), No. 9 in the IBD 50, was also slated to issue quarterly results after hours, but hadn't reported immediately after the bell.

In Wednesday's regular session, the market moved higher in the afternoon following the Fed's policy announcement and Ben Bernanke's news conference. Officials gave most investors the impression that a rate hike should not be expected soon. They also said the central bank's $600 billion bond-buying program will stop by the end of June as planned.

Thursday's economic news will include an advance estimate for U.S. Q1 GDP. The companies slated to post quarterly results include ViroPharma (VPHM), Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP), HealthSpring (HS), Deckers Outdoor (DECK), Ancestry.com (ACOM), Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Procter & Gamble (PG).

After a modestly upbeat start, stocks trimmed gains or slouched to small losses.The Nasdaq was down 0.1%, after being up 0.3%. The S&P 500 trimmed an early 0.2% gain to 0.1%. The NYSE composite was up 0.4% but had been up 0.8% earlier.Volume was down across the board. Among IBD's 197 industry groups, oil and mining stocks were strong. Restaurants and computer networking and software stocks were weak.Cloud-based business software provider Salesforce.com (CRM) advanced 3% in heavy volume. Morgan Stanley upgraded the stock from equal weight to overweight. The stock is a member of IBD's Big Cap 20.Deckers Outdoor (DECK) popped 2% in 30% faster volume as it retook its 50-day moving average. The Ugg boots maker cleared a base in February but triggered the 8% sell rule in mid-March. The decline eventually evolved into a base on base, which Deckers cleared in low volume in April. But shares fell more than 8% from the buy point. Now Deckers is consolidating again.Medical-waste management company Stericycle (SRCL) fell 1% in more than twice its usual volume, a day after diving under its 50-day line.Cigarette maker Lorillard (LO) fell 2% in strong volume. It was the sharpest loss since the stock cleared a consolidation in March. Lorillard is only 3% off its 52-week high. Defensive stocks, such as tobacco, have been leaders in recent months.
The major indexes rebounded to near session highs in late-afternoon action Thursday.
The NYSE composite leapt 2.9%, the S&P 500 2.4%, and the Dow and Nasdaq 2.2% each. But turnover continued to track slightly lower across the board.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) motored 5% in triple its normal trade, though it was off its session high. The athletic apparel maker posted first-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share, topping Wall Street's consensus of 21 cents. The company also raised its full-year profit and revenue projections.

Ulta Salon (ULTA) picked up 2% in above-average volume. The beauty-store chain operator is trying to bounce back to its 50-day moving average. Its Accumulation/Distribution has fallen to a poor D+ during the market's correction.

Stericycle (SRCL) also climbed 2% in rapid turnover. The medical waste management stock is closing in on its all-time high, set in September 2008. Stocks remained in deep red late Monday, but have pared some losses. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 dropped 1.4% and 1.1%, respectively. Both were still below their 50-day moving averages breached earlier in the session. All three were down between 1.5% and 1.9% at session lows. Tech Data (TECD) gapped below its 50-day moving average and plunged 12% after missing…

The major indexes lost ground in early trade Friday, as the market pointed to a potential second straight down day in higher volume.The Nasdaq shed 0.2%, the S&P 500 0.5%, the Dow 0.6% and the NYSE composite 0.9%. Volume swelled 15% on the NYSE and 26% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Thursday.Eldorado Gold (EGO) slipped 2% in brisk trade. The gold mining firm sits 4% off its 52-week high, having build a point of resistance around 19.Alaska Air Group (ALK) shed 3% in rapid turnover. The airline carrier's stock found support at its 50-day moving average.Stericycle (SRCL) lost 2% in heavy volume. The waste management services provider's stock has pulled back after briefly touching a new high in weak trade on Wednesday.
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes fell in early trade Wednesday, as investors looked past some encouraging news on the earnings front.
The Nasdaq fell 0.5%, the NYSE composite 0.1%. The S&P 500 and Dow were both trading flat. Volume rose 4% on the NYSE and 18% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
Bucyrus (BUCY) gapped up 4% in heavy volume. The mining equipment maker surged above its 200-day moving average.
Netflix (NFLX) added 2% in fast trade. The online movie rental subscription service provider is slated to report second-quarter earnings results after the closing bell.

On the downside, Stericycle (SRCL) shed 4% in rapid turnover. The waste management service provider remained well above its 50-day line.BY JONAH KERIThe major indexes fell in early trade Wednesday, as investors looked past some encouraging news on the earnings front.The Nasdaq fell 0.5%, the NYSE composite 0.1%. The S&P 500 and Dow were both trading flat. Volume rose 4% on the NYSE and 18% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.Bucyrus (BUCY) gapped up 4% in heavy volume. The waste management service provider remained well above its 50-day line.

Stocks achieved strong gains Monday, as the Nasdaq and S&P 500 stretched their winning streaks to four straight sessions. The NYSE composite fared best with a 1.4% advance, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 rose 1.2% and 1%, respectively. Volume increased on both main exchanges from Monday's levels, giving extra punch to the move up. All three indexes climbed above…
Stocks maintained their solid gains in midafternoon action Tuesday, but they had pulled back from their session highs.
The Nasdaq was up 1.2%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.9%. Volume increased from Monday's levels on both main exchanges.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 are on pace to close above their 50-day moving averages for the first time since early May. Many highly rated stocks have executed breakouts Tuesday.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI) jumped 4% in fast trade, as the stock made its third attempt at advancing past a 39.41 buy point from a flat base. Texas Capital moved above 39.41 on June 11 and June 13, but couldn't close above the trigger, although it never fell so much as to trip IBD's 7% or 8% sell rule. The stock is No. 26 in Monday's IBD 50 lineup.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) rose 5% in heavy turnover. The drugmaker moved past a flat-base entry at 95.11, as well as a possible handle buy point at 94.46. Alexion is No. 4 in the IBD 50.

SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) was up less than 1% in big volume, as it gave up gains after topping a 100.60 flat-base buy point earlier Tuesday. The pharmacy benefits manager is now holding below 100.60. It's No. 3 in the IBD 50.

Ashland (ASH) rose 3% in strong volume, clearing a 67.69 buy point from a square-box base. The chemicals maker isn't in the IBD 50, but it has an IBD Composite Rating of 98, near the best-possible grade of 99.
Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) gained 2% in strong turnover, as it topped a 27.84 entry from a flat base. The beauty products retailer has an excellent Composite Rating of 98.

Stericycle (SRCL) advanced 3% in active turnover, moving above a long consolidation with resistance around the 90 level. The medical waste handler has an 85 Composite Rating, which is respectable but not stellar, in part due to its relatively modest quarterly gains in EPS and revenue.

Microsoft (MSFT) rose 4% in big trade, helped by its announcement late Monday that it's entering the tablet market with its new Surface device. The tech giant has lifted above its 50-day line and now stands about 6% off its 52-week high. Microsoft showed only single-digit percentage gains in quarterly EPS and revenue in the last two quarters. It has an OK Composite Rating of 82.

Oracle (ORCL) gained 4% in strong turnover. Late Monday, the company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for its fiscal fourth quarter. It posted its Q4 results three days ahead of schedule. Oracle had been up as much as 6% out of the gate. The stock, which has a middling Composite Rating of 69, has climbed above its 50-day line, but it remains about 17% below its 52-week high.

On the downside, Walgreen (WAG) tumbled 6% in huge volume after agreeing to pay $6.7 billion for a 45% stake in Europe's largest pharmacy chain, Alliance Boots. The cash-stock deal is Walgreen's first overseas venture. Walgreen said it expects the deal to close by September. It has a weak Composite Rating of 31 and is trading below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

In economic news, housing starts for May dropped to 708,000 units, missing forecasts, but new building permits increased and topped expectations. In addition, upward revisions to March's and April's figures mean that housing starts have topped 700,000 for five months in a row.

While events in Europe remain crucial, the market could be focused on possible results from the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which began today and ends Wednesday afternoon. Much of the market expects, and a Goldman Sachs note on Tuesday forecast, an easing of monetary policy. Possible tactics could include buying of mortgage-backed securities or bonds, aimed at adding downward pressure on interest rates. Stocks were narrowly split in early trading Friday after the government reported mixed jobs data.The Nasdaq climbed 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and NYSE composite slipped 0.1%. Volume was tracking higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.Stericycle (SRCL) gapped up and surged 10% to a record high. The stock gapped above an 82.31 buy point in a square-box base. Late Thursday, the medical waste management firm topped expectations with a 26% rise in Q4 earnings. Earlier Friday, Wedbush raised shares to outperform from neutral.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) climbed 4% to a fresh record high. It cleared a six-week flat base. At just about 30 minutes into the trading session, the stock has already traded more than 30% of its average daily volume. Lululemon sells yoga apparel and accessories. Last month, the retailer raised its outlook for Q1 earnings sales.Trimble Navigation (TRMB) gapped up and gained 4% to an all-time high. That puts it 12% past a 42.29 buy point from a square-box pattern cleared Jan. 14. After Thursday's close, the GPS device firm smashed views with a 116% surge in Q4 earnings and a 17% rise in sales. It guided Q1 profit and revenue above views.On the downside, NetSuite (N) gapped down and slumped nearly 6%, then trimmed its loss to 3%. Late Thursday, the software maker reported Q4 earnings that matched expectations, while sales beat views. But the firm pegged full-year 2011 profit of 16 cents to 19 cents a share vs. analysts' consensus of 22 cents.Amtech Systems (ASYS) fell 3% in fast trade and neared its 50-day moving average. According to the EE Times Asia, the chip and solar equipment maker agreed to buy a majority stake in Kingstone Technology Hong Kong.
Some better-than-expected economic data helped stocks to modest gains, following the prior session's heavy losses.
The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and NYSE composite rose 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Volume was tracking sharply higher in the early going.

In economic news, pending home sales surprisingly rose 2.4% in June vs. expectations for a 3% drop. But the National Association of Realtors said the number of cancellations jumped 16% vs. an average of about 4%.

GNC Holdings (GNC) gapped up and surge 16% after besting profit estimates. The nutritional supplements retailer reported a Q2 profit of 40 cents a share, up 60%. It beat views by 8 cents. Sales climbed 14% to $518.5 billion, the biggest gain in many quarters. GNC came public in April
Dunkin' Brands Group (DNKN) bolted out of the gate and surged 9%. But it has since trimmed its gain to 2%. Dunkin' came public Wednesday.

On the downside, Carbo Ceramics (CRR) gapped down and tumbled 7% despite beating views. The company delivered Q2 earnings of $1.29 a share, up 59% and a penny above views. Sales grew 34% to $149.7 million, also above views. Carbo makes ceramic proppant, a key ingredient used by drillers to crack underground rock to free trapped oil and gas. The stock is now 5% below a 169.44 buy point from a cup-without-handle base.

Stericycle (SRCL) gapped below its 50-day moving average and slumped nearly 5% in heavy trading. Late Wednesday, the medical waste recycler reported Q2 earnings of 69 cents a share, up 11% and in line with estimates. That marked the slowest growth in many quarters. Sales, which beat expectations, rose 18%.

Sprint Nextel (S) gapped down, plummeting 17% in heavy trading. reported a larger-than-expected loss for the second quarter. The mobile phone services company, which has traded below 10 a share for more than three years, fell to its mid-March lows.

Stocks rolled ahead Thursday, but low volume muted the move's thunder. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video! The Nasdaq added 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the NYSE composite 0.5%. Volume slipped 8% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE. The Nasdaq dropped an old distribution day…
Stocks hovered near session lows after having a big change of heart earlier.

The Nasdaq dropped 1.4% after having been up as much as 0.8% shortly after the open. The tech-heavy index breached its 200-day moving average and came close to its 50-day line. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 lost 1.1%, falling back below the 1100 level. The Dow fell 0.8% and NYSE composite 0.7%.
Chip issues were among the hardest hit.

NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) gapped down and dumped 8% in heavy trading. Late Wednesday, the chipmaker beat views with a second straight period of triple-digit profit growth. But sales came in a tad below analysts' estimates. Earlier Thursday, UBS lowered its price target to $33.50 from $34.50.

Volterra Semiconductor (VLTR) erased opening gains, shed 6% and breach its 200-day moving average. Earlier this week, the firm delivered Q2 results above view and guided Q3 earnings in line with consensus estimates.
OmniVision Technologies (OVTI) lost 2% as it fell further south of a 24.39 buy point from a square box cleared Monday.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index dropped 2.7% and tested its 200-day moving average.

Elsewhere, Stericycle (SRCL) gapped down and dropped 4%, despite reporting Q2 results above views late Wednesday. Earlier Thursday, Soleil cut the provider of medical waste services to hold from buy on valuation.

On the upside, Citrix Systems (CTXS) gapped up and surged 17%, ignoring the market reversal. It bolted out of a three-month base. After Wednesday's close, the business software maker reported Q2 earnings that missed sales. But its sales beat views and it gave an upbeat revenue outlook for the year. An equipment failure during a high-pressure, hydraulic fracturing operation at a Pennsylvania gas well April 19 released a surge of chemical-laced fluids onto the well site and a nearby stream. The accident, which required the temporary evacuation of a number of families near the site, occurred in LeRoy Township, Pa., at a well owned and operated by Chesapeake Energy (CHK).…

Stocks tried to rally in afternoon trade Monday as they cut some of the day's sharp losses.The Nasdaq was down 1.2%, the S&P 500 1.4% while the NYSE composite fell 1.5%. Small caps and midcaps were down more as the S&P 600 and the S&P 400 skidded 1.8%. Volume was up about 1% on the Nasdaq and down about 4% on the NYSE, suggesting that institutional investors were selling selectively but not pushing the panic button.Among top-rated stocks, losers moving in fast trade dominated winners moving in fast trade.Construction and mining equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT) dived 4% in heavy volume. The stock sliced through its 50-day line. Caterpillar's last five new highs made en route to a peak on April 4 were all made in below-average volume. Since then, it's corrected about 9% with three declines coming in above-average volume. That picture points to distribution.In most cases, though, the chart action of top-rated stocks didn't look especially dangerous.Mining equipment maker Joy Global (JOYG) cut under its 50-day line as it shed 4%. But volume was below normal. The stock is 10% off its 52-week high.Silver Wheaton (SLW) dropped 3% in nearly double its average volume. But the stock was finding support at its 50-day moving average.Tractor Supply (TSCO) slid 3% in 39% heavier volume, but the farm store chain stock remains well above its 50-day line. Tractor Supply will report quarterly results Wednesday. The Street expects earnings to rise 23% and revenue 12% on a year-ago basis. The company has topped analysts' estimates for nine consecutive quarters.Other top-rated stocks — such as Priceline.com (PCLN), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Stericycle (SRCL) and somewhat thinly traded iRobot (IRBT) — fell in below-average volume. The stocks were not undercutting recent lows, which gave their action a sideways look.

As the world grows, people will gobble up more food and use more stuff, which creates more garbage. And one person's trash is another's treasure, especially for companies in the Global X Waste Management ETF (WSTE), which launched Wednesday. Tracking the Solactive Global Waste Management Index, WSTE holds 28 companies engaged in recycling and disposal of hazardous or nonhazardous waste.…
President Obama's agenda the next four years could be a boon or a bust for some stock sectors. Here's an overview of what investing strategists say are the best sectors to buy and steer clear of.
 Health care: Among myriad changes, the sweeping ObamaCare plan enables more than 30 million uninsured Americans to receive health insurance.
This brings an onslaught of new customers to hospitals, health insurers and drugmakers, but the added rules make it difficult to determine how profitable they'll be.
For example, health insurance plans have to provide preventative services without copays, do away with annual and lifetime coverage limits and cover new patients with pre-existing conditions.
Automatic federal spending cuts slated for next year would trim Medicare payments to hospitals by more than $5.8 billion and drug benefits by $591 million.

The winners and losers will vary depending on whom you ask, and there are just too many issues that still need to be worked out, said Robert Laura, president of Synergos Financial Group with $25 million in assets under management in Brighton, Mich.

He believes investors' best bets lie with firms akin to those who sold picks and shovels during the gold rush. Those include Stericycle (SRCL), the medical-waste disposal king, and McKesson (MCK), a tech firm serving all aspects of the health care industry.
Real estate investment trusts specializing in health care facilities or hospitals will also benefit from increased health care spending.
John Graves, editor of "The Retirement Journal" recommends Health Care REIT (HCN), Ventas (VTR), Medical Properties Trust (MPW) and Sabra Health Care REIT (SBRA).
While plenty of health care ETFs and REIT ETFs exist, none invest only in health care REITs, health care technology or medical waste.
Biggest 2nd-Term Losers
 Aerospace and defense: Federal budget cuts set to go into effect January amount to $109 billion through Sept. 30, 2013, and $984 billion over nine years.
Navy aircraft spending is slated to be reduced by $2.2 billion, or 9.4%, and Army operations $6.9 billion, or 9.4%.

That will have an impact on the bottom lines of Boeing (BA) and Lockheed Martin (LMT), which make military aircraft and missiles, said Jonathan Hill. As an investment strategist at Gibraltar Private Bank & Trust in Coral Gables, Fla., he manages more than $600 million in client assets.
Both stocks are major holdings in iShares Dow Jones U.S. Aerospace & Defense  (ITA) and PowerShares Aerospace & Defense  (PPA).

Most of the blue chip defense and aerospace contractors pay a dividend that could be cut should profit and sales decline, said Robert Luna. He's CEO and chief investment officer at SureVest Capital Management in Phoenix, Ariz., with $100 million in assets under management.
"I don't think the worst-case scenario has been priced into them yet," Luna said.
 Coal: The coal industry, which accounts for 42% for the country's electricity, had already been suffering from having to compete with free-falling natural gas prices the past four years.
Some older coal plants have been forced to close because of expensive upgrades required by toxic emissions regulations that were already on the way before Obama took office.
Coal producers are bracing for harsher emissions rules in Obama's second term.
Market Vectors Coal ETF (KOL) plunged 5.5% the day after the election.
It's lost 27.13% year to date, much steeper than the 4.86% loss for energy stocks tracked by Morningstar Inc.

J. Camarda, chairman and chief investment officer of Camarda Wealth Advisory Group in Fleming Island, Fla., expects KOL to fall to new lows. Camarda has $250 million in assets under management.President Obama's agenda the next four years could be a boon or a bust for some stock sectors. Stocks ended solidly higher Tuesday but pulled back from their intraday highs amid hopes for more Federal Reserve stimulus. The Nasdaq was up 1.2%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.7%. Volume increased from Monday's levels on the Nasdaq and NYSE. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 closed above their 50-day moving averages for the first time…
The major indexes achieved solid gains Tuesday, closing near their session highs.
The major indexes achieved solid gains Tuesday, closing near their session highs.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!
The S&P 500 rose 0.9% while the Nasdaq and NYSE both advanced 0.8%. Volume increased across the board from Monday's unusually low levels, according to preliminary data.
After hours, a bevy of top-rated companies were reporting quarterly results.

Acme Packet (APKT) traded sharply lower in the extended session even as it posted Q1 EPS and sales that beat forecasts. The networking gear maker also guided 2011 EPS and sales roughly in line with views.

During the regular session, Acme fell 3% in strong volume, finishing back below its recent 77.35 handle buy point. Acme etched a bearish railroad tracks in early March, but had been behaving well in recent weeks.

Amazon.com (AMZN) initially fell after hours, then turned positive. It reported Q1 EPS that missed views, but revenue bested forecasts. The e-commerce giant has been consolidating in the vicinity of its 10-week moving average for several months. Amazon has an IBD Composite Rating of 84, solid but below the best-possible rating of 99.

On the upside, Altera (ALTR) moved higher in late trading as it posted better-than-anticipated Q1 results. It initially fell after hours, then recovered. During the regular session, the chip designer jumped 2% in above-average volume, closing up about 5% above a 44.47 buy point from a short cup with handle.
Baidu (BIDU), Stericycle (SRCL), ARM Holdings (ARMH) and Starbucks (SBUX) are among the highly rated firms slated to report quarterly results Wednesday.
The day's economic news will include the Fed's latest policy decision and Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke's news conference.

As earnings season rolls on, a barrage of IBD 50 stocks will report earnings this week.

Baidu (BIDU) late Monday easily beat views with Q2 earnings of 72 cents a share, up 106%. The "Chinese Google" extended its streak of triple-digit earnings gains to six quarters. Sales grew 87% to $528.4 million vs. views of $502 million.
The stock is extended after clearing a 139.19 buy point in a double-bottom base June 30.

Carbo Ceramics (CRR) is the world's biggest maker of proppant, a key ingredient used by drillers to break through underground rock and free trapped oil and gas. The firm reports Q2 results on Thursday. Analysts see profit rising 56% to $1.26 a share. The estimate has been raised nine times since February. Revenue is expected to rise 30% to $144.9 million.

Cliff's Natural Resources (CLF) missed earnings expectations late Wednesday as shares sold off in extended trading. The company, the largest producer of iron ore pellets in the U.S. Iron ore used in making steel, sustained sharply higher expenses.

Mattress maker Tempur-Pedic International (TPX) remained near its 10-week line after posting Q2 results Tuesday. The company reported profit of 76 cents a share, up 65% from a year ago. Revenue rose 30% to $342.2 million.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) reports after Thursday's close. The drugmaker's bread-and-butter product is its Xyrem narcolepsy treatment. Last year, Xyrem sales accounted for more than 80% of total revenue. One-product companies can be more risky.
The company's Q2 earnings are expected to surge 175% to 77 cents a share. Sales are expected at $60.5 million, up 49%.
Telnav (TNAV), Deckers Outdoor (DECK) and Stericycle (SRCL) will also report results this week.
