Stocks maintained their solid gains in midafternoon action Tuesday, but they had pulled back from their session highs.
The Nasdaq was up 1.2%, the S&P 500 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.9%. Volume increased from Monday's levels on both main exchanges.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 are on pace to close above their 50-day moving averages for the first time since early May. Many highly rated stocks have executed breakouts Tuesday.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI) jumped 4% in fast trade, as the stock made its third attempt at advancing past a 39.41 buy point from a flat base. Texas Capital moved above 39.41 on June 11 and June 13, but couldn't close above the trigger, although it never fell so much as to trip IBD's 7% or 8% sell rule. The stock is No. 26 in Monday's IBD 50 lineup.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) rose 5% in heavy turnover. The drugmaker moved past a flat-base entry at 95.11, as well as a possible handle buy point at 94.46. Alexion is No. 4 in the IBD 50.

SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) was up less than 1% in big volume, as it gave up gains after topping a 100.60 flat-base buy point earlier Tuesday. The pharmacy benefits manager is now holding below 100.60. It's No. 3 in the IBD 50.

Ashland (ASH) rose 3% in strong volume, clearing a 67.69 buy point from a square-box base. The chemicals maker isn't in the IBD 50, but it has an IBD Composite Rating of 98, near the best-possible grade of 99.
Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) gained 2% in strong turnover, as it topped a 27.84 entry from a flat base. The beauty products retailer has an excellent Composite Rating of 98.

Stericycle (SRCL) advanced 3% in active turnover, moving above a long consolidation with resistance around the 90 level. The medical waste handler has an 85 Composite Rating, which is respectable but not stellar, in part due to its relatively modest quarterly gains in EPS and revenue.

Microsoft (MSFT) rose 4% in big trade, helped by its announcement late Monday that it's entering the tablet market with its new Surface device. The tech giant has lifted above its 50-day line and now stands about 6% off its 52-week high. Microsoft showed only single-digit percentage gains in quarterly EPS and revenue in the last two quarters. It has an OK Composite Rating of 82.

Oracle (ORCL) gained 4% in strong turnover. Late Monday, the company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for its fiscal fourth quarter. It posted its Q4 results three days ahead of schedule. Oracle had been up as much as 6% out of the gate. The stock, which has a middling Composite Rating of 69, has climbed above its 50-day line, but it remains about 17% below its 52-week high.

On the downside, Walgreen (WAG) tumbled 6% in huge volume after agreeing to pay $6.7 billion for a 45% stake in Europe's largest pharmacy chain, Alliance Boots. The cash-stock deal is Walgreen's first overseas venture. Walgreen said it expects the deal to close by September. It has a weak Composite Rating of 31 and is trading below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

In economic news, housing starts for May dropped to 708,000 units, missing forecasts, but new building permits increased and topped expectations. In addition, upward revisions to March's and April's figures mean that housing starts have topped 700,000 for five months in a row.

While events in Europe remain crucial, the market could be focused on possible results from the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which began today and ends Wednesday afternoon. Much of the market expects, and a Goldman Sachs note on Tuesday forecast, an easing of monetary policy. Possible tactics could include buying of mortgage-backed securities or bonds, aimed at adding downward pressure on interest rates. The medical waste handler has an 85 Composite Rating, which is respectable but not stellar, in part due to its relatively modest quarterly gains in EPS and revenue.Microsoft (MSFT) rose 4% in big trade, helped by its announcement late Monday that it's entering the tablet market with its new Surface device. The tech giant has lifted above its 50-day line and now stands about 6% off its 52-week high. Microsoft showed only single-digit percentage gains in quarterly EPS and revenue in the last two quarters. It has an OK Composite Rating of 82.Oracle (ORCL) gained 4% in strong turnover. Late Monday, the company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for its fiscal fourth quarter. It posted its Q4 results three days ahead of schedule. Oracle had been up as much as 6% out of the gate. The stock, which has a middling Composite Rating of 69, has climbed above its 50-day line, but it remains about 17% below its 52-week high.On the downside, Walgreen (WAG) tumbled 6% in huge volume after agreeing to pay $6.7 billion for a 45% stake in Europe's largest pharmacy chain, Alliance Boots. The cash-stock deal is Walgreen's first overseas venture. Walgreen said it expects the deal to close by September. It has a weak Composite Rating of 31 and is trading below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.In economic news, housing starts for May dropped to 708,000 units, missing forecasts, but new building permits increased and topped expectations. In addition, upward revisions to March's and April's figures mean that housing starts have topped 700,000 for five months in a row.While events in Europe remain crucial, the market could be focused on possible results from the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which began today and ends Wednesday afternoon. Much of the market expects, and a Goldman Sachs note on Tuesday forecast, an easing of monetary policy. Possible tactics could include buying of mortgage-backed securities or bonds, aimed at adding downward pressure on interest rates. An announcement is expected Wednesday at 12:30 p.m. ET.
Most IBD 50 stocks have added gains since last week's relief rally, but market conditions remain challenging for new breakouts. Also, some leaders are well extended from their buy points.
Nevertheless, a number of elite stocks keep working on bases and have moved closer to possible entry points, such as Ancestry.com (ACOM), Catalyst Health Solutions (CHSI) and Priceline.com (PCLN).

Ancestry is forming the right side of a new base that's part of a larger base-on-base structure. It's a family history website that came public in 2009 and has drawn increasing institutional sponsorship. Unless the stock tacks on a handle, the potential buy point would be 45.89.
Catalyst, a pharmacy benefits manager, regained its 10-week moving average last week as it kept consolidating. It's still about 9% off its May high.

Priceline, a longtime leader, is etching a third-stage base with a possible entry at 561.98. Volume has been light as the online travel broker has shaped this consolidation's right side. If Priceline manages to clear 561.98, you want to see strong turnover with that move.

Some other basing IBD 50 names are chip designer Altera (ALTR) and medical waste handler Stericycle (SRCL). The former, however, has fallen sharply this week and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has dived to a worst-possible E.

Generic drugs producer Perrigo (PRGO) broke out past its new buy point at 92.40 in solid volume on Wednesday but closed slightly below that price. It added gains on Thursday to buck the market's decline and close slightly above the proper entry point.

Some leaders tried to break out last week but quickly ran into trouble. VMware (VMW) stands 2% below its 102.84 trigger it topped Wednesday July 6. Accretive Health (AH), which provides financial services to health care organizations, surged out of a base Wednesday, but quickly made a bearish reversal.
Ugg boots maker Deckers Outdoor (DECK) and Carbo Ceramics (CRR), which provides a key product to oil and gas firms, both topped buy points, but volume was unconvincing.
Plus, Illumina (ILMN) jumped past a 76.91 entry point Tuesday July 5, but finished the week under that level. Still, the developer of genetic-analysis tools hasn't triggered any sell rules.

For the week ended July 8, IBD 50 stocks rose 2.1% on average. The Nasdaq rose 1.6%, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.3%. The NYSE dipped 0.2%Most IBD 50 stocks have added gains since last week's relief rally, but market conditions remain challenging for new breakouts. The major indexes mostly finished a little lower on Wednesday, as traders took time to absorb Tuesday's big gain and weigh the latest clashes in Egypt.
The major indexes mostly finished a little lower on Wednesday, as traders took time to absorb Tuesday's big gain and weigh the latest clashes in Egypt.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!
The Nasdaq shed less than 0.1%, while the NYSE fell 0.2% and the S&P 500 lost 0.3%. The Dow gained a fraction. Volume declined across the board, according to preliminary data.

After hours, NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) gained ground as it posted Q4 EPS of 45 cents, topping views. The chip designer reported revenue of $100.4 million, just ahead of forecasts. The stock, which rose 1% in the regular session, has climbed back above its 10-week moving average after a failed breakout past a 34.45 handle buy point. It's now trading back above that buy point, after having triggered the 7% to 8% sell rule.

In Wednesday's regular session, Informatica (INFA) cleared a short consolidation and reached a new high, as the stock jumped 2% in strong trade. The provider of data integration software has advanced for four straight sessions since posting quarterly earnings that beat views late on Jan. 27.

Acme Packet (APKT) was one of Wednesday's biggest winners, as the networking gear maker surged 20% in huge turnover. The stock is extended after multiple pullbacks to its 10-week moving average since May of 2010. Late Tuesday, Acme Packet posted strong quarterly results.

Economic reports came in positive on Wednesday morning. The ADP employment survey said the economy added 187,000 private-sector jobs last month, beating views. Outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas said planned layoffs dropped 46% in January vs. a year ago, representing the largest year-over-year decline since August.

The economic data expected on Thursday include chain store sales for January, a jobless claims report and a factory orders report. JDS Uniphase (JDSU), Stericycle (SRCL), Radware (RDWR), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Dow Chemical (DOW) are among the many notable companies slated to post quarterly earnings on Thursday.

Stocks rebounded from recent losses to score their first gain in three days Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average led, rising 0.9%. The S&P 500 rose 0.8%, recouping most of Friday's loss. But the Nasdaq lagged with a 0.6% gain. Still, the tech-laden index closed back above the 4000 level, despite continued weakness in biotech stocks. The Medical-Biomed/Biotech industry group…

Stocks pulled in two directions for most of Thursday's session, with the Nasdaq up and the other major indexes down. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks? Click here to watch the latest Market Wrap video! But the bears took control in the final hour, pulling the Nasdaq into negative territory. The Nasdaq lost 0.5% after…

Stocks rallied through most of Friday's session but then gave up a chunk of the gains. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video! The NYSE composite added 0.8% and the S&P 500 0.5%. The Nasdaq, which had been up as much as 0.8%, closed up 0.3%. Volume rose on…

Stocks rebounded into positive territory Tuesday, as a late surge netted gains in higher volume for the market. The Dow industrials led with a 1.8% gain. The S&P 500 rose 1%, the NYSE composite 0.8%. The Nasdaq eked out a 0.1% gain. Volume picked up 14% on the NYSE and 26% on the Nasdaq compared with Monday's levels. The major…
5:15 p.m. Update: Indexes rose in a late surge, capping a volatile session with solid gains Tuesday.

The NYSE composite led throughout the session, leaping to a 4.3% gain in the final 90 minutes of trading. The S&P 500 closed with a 4% win. The Nasdaq and the Dow claimed 3.7% and 3.3% advances, respectively.
Small caps led the late surge, with the S&P 600 acing a 5.3% advance. The NYSE financial index hurtled 6.4% higher.
Preliminary data showed volume 10% higher on the Nasdaq and down 1% on the NYSE.

The Nasdaq gains and volume  if confirmed  were such that they constitute a follow-through of the markets' rally attempt launched Nov. 21. Check for a final read in the Big Picture in tomorrow's IBD.
Big winners among leading stocks included Balchem (BCPC), Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) and Gentiva (GTIV).
United Therapeutics (UTHR) managed to erase early losses and closed 2% higher.

For Wednesday, the ADP employment report, a measure of nonfarm private employment, is due out prior to the market's open. The Institute for Supply Management's Services Index is due out at 10 a.m. EST.
The Fed's beige book, a broad survey by sector of economic activity across the U.S., is slated for a 2 p.m. EST release.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Surge In Final Hour
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market burst higher in the final hour Tuesday, regaining its composure after having erased morning gains.
The NYSE composite surged 4.3%, the S&P 500 4%, the Nasdaq 3.7% and the Dow 3.3%, according to preliminary figures.
Volume rose from Monday's levels.
Advancing stocks led decliners by 5-to-2 on the NYSE and by more than 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Auto-related stocks led as automakers presented recovery plans to Congress. Real estate, building and other low-rated industry groups also fared best.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Battle Back Some In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
With just about an hour remaining in Tuesday's session, stocks rebounded after giving up most of their session winnings.
The NYSE composite climbed 1.7%, but that's down from an intraday high of 4.3%. The Nasdaq gained 1.3%, S&P 500 1.2% and Dow 0.8%.
Turnover was still tracking higher across the board. Auto, building and some industrial groups led the market.
Despite the improvement, the number of heavy-volume gainers dried up considerably.
Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) jumped 12% in heavy trading following a stellar earnings report late Monday. But it eased off a 16% intraday peak.
Yahoo (YHOO) climbed 6% on report that an ex-AOL executive may bid for the company.
On the downside, Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) fell nearly 4% and dropped further south of its 50-day moving average. The business information firm was added to the S&P 500 Monday.
Crude oil settled at $46.96 a barrel, down $2.32. Oil-related industry groups were mostly lower.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Pull Back; Volume Remains High
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks trimmed gains in afternoon trading, as the number of high-rated stocks falling in high volume outpaced those rising in fast trade.
The Dow rose 2.1%, the S&P 500 2.7%, the NYSE composite 3.1%. The Nasdaq was up 2.6%.
Volume was tracking higher. Advancing stocks led decliners by about 2-to-1 on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.

Nippon Telegraph & Telephone (NTT) rose 6%. The Japanese telecom gapped up in high volume and retook its 200-day moving average, which is higher than its 50-day line. The stock may be approaching a buy point in a sloppy, V-shaped cup-with-handle base.

On the downside, Research In Motion (RIMM) is off 7%. The maker of the BlackBerry smart phone hit a 26-month low on results from Palm (PALM), a rival. Palm announced that sales of its Treo and Centro smart phones were $190 million, missing forecasts for $331.8 million.
Palm shares  now trading below 2  were down 8%, up from an intraday loss of 39%.

Flowers Foods (FLO), a maker of bakery products, fell 3%. That's a comeback from the day's low, an 8% drop. The stock sold off Monday, losing 7%. The company had looked like it was shaping a base since August, but the base was sloppy. Today's low undercut the base.
1:15 p.m. Update: Rebound Overrides Weak Auto Sales Data
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT

Citigroup (C)and Bank of America (BAC) led the Dow higher and Liberty Media (LINTA) and Sears Holdings (SHLD) topped the Nasdaq 100 as indexes continued taking back more of Monday's sharp losses. Auto makers began to report November light vehicle sales, with Ford (F) posting a 31% decline and Toyota (TM) reporting a 34% drop from a year ago.
The NYSE composite continued to lead, up 3.7%. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite rose to 3.4% and 3.3% gains. The Dow climbed 2.8%, held back by declines in 3M  (MMM) and Coca Cola (KO).
Volume picked up steadily, up 6% on the NYSE and 9% on the Nasdaq.
Oil prices were down slightly, between $48 and $49 a barrel.
Astec Industries (ASTE) powered up 9% in firm volume. The heavy excavation and mining equipment maker had slid 14% on Monday. The stock is trying to craft a right side to a monthlong base.
Shire  (SHPGY) edged up 2% in healthy volume, preparing for its third test of resistance at its 50-day moving average this month.
On the downside, United Therapeutics (UTHR) slipped 3%, leaving the biotech drug maker near its lows after a 35% sell-off Nov. 17.
12:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Reach For Session Highs on Solid Volume
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Financials and technology issues led as indexes pressed higher at noon.
The NYSE composite broke out to a 3.6% gain. The S&P 500 and the NYSE composite pulsed 3.2% and 3% higher. The Dow pulled up 2.8%.
Midcaps continued to head the gains, with the S&P 400 up 3.8%. All but two Dow components gained ground and nine-in-10 Nasdaq 100 stocks moved higher.
Volume continued to improve from early, mixed levels, up 4% on the NYSE and 5% higher on the Nasdaq.
Oil came under some pressure, slipping to a 45-month low below $48 a barrel.

Stocks on the rebound included Clean Harbors (CLHB), which jumped 3%. The moved lifted shares back to near their 50-day moving average as the stock tries to flesh out a bottom to a three-month consolidation.
Medical waste collection firm Stericycle (SRCL) popped for a 4% gain. That took back a portion of Monday's 11% drop, but left shares well below key levels of support.
Strayer Education (STRA) hauled in a 5% advance. That returned shares to just below the 236.60 buy point cleared in last week's breakout from a cup-with-high-handle base.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Retake Some Ground As Volume Rises
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Stocks and commodities rebounded from Monday's sharp losses as U.S. automakers bargained with Congress for billions in taxpayer funding and as oil prices held largely unchanged.
The NYSE composite led, up 2.9%. The Nasdaq composite held a 2.4% gain and the S&P 500 rode 2.4% higher. The Dow added 2%.
Trading volume was up, slightly higher on the Nasdaq and the NYSE.
Midcaps ran ahead of the crowd, the S&P 400 up 3.6% with Medicis Pharmaceuticals (MRX) and Williams Sonoma (WSM) posting the index's best gains.
Oil rose by pennies, but held below $50 a barrel. Gold and most commodities moved higher. The dollar slipped vs. the euro but gained some ground against the yen.

World Fuel Services (INT) jumped 6%, grabbing back most of Monday's 5% slide. The marine and aircraft fuels distributor broke above a 12-week cup-base Nov. 10. Tuesday's move lifted it back above the cup's 30.31 buy point.
Technical school operator DeVry (DV) sparked 7% higher, also taking back its dip from Monday. That left shares just below the 58.87 buy point in an 11-week, cup-with-high handle base.

On the downside, NCI (NCIT) tumbled 8%, compounding its 7% loss from Monday. That left the government IT services contractor just above its 50-day moving average, and 10% below a 26.95 buy point after a failed breakout attempt last week.
Overseas, Monday's confirmation of global recession bit deep, driving Hong Kong's Hang Seng index down 5%. Property and financial issues led the decline. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 unraveled 6.4%.

Things looked better in Europe and the U.K. as energy issues rebounded from Monday's sell-off. The DAX in Frankfurt, Germany, tacked on 1.7%. The CAC-40 in Paris showed a 0.9% gain and the FTSE 100 in London was 0.4% higher in afternoon trading.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Open Higher, But Gains Fading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened to the upside Tuesday, recouping a bit of Monday's hefty losses. But gains have waned since the opening bell and the Nasdaq nearly went negative.
The NYSE composite was up 1.2%, the S&P 500 0.7%, the Nasdaq 0.5% and the Dow 0.4%.
Volume was tracking sharply lower in the early going.

Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) rose 14% following a stellar Q3 report. Late Monday, the online gaming firm said earnings climbed to 68 cents a share, up 55% from a year earlier and 10 cents above views. Sales grew 43% to $137 million, also above views. The company also announced investments in two leading gaming communities.
Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 3% in fast trade. The retailer bounced back after sliding 7% in the prior session's sell-off. The stock remains just under a 40.58 buy point.
3M  (MMM) lost 3% and fell further south of its 50-day moving average after Citigroup cut the diversified manufacturer to sell from hold on concerns about a strong dollar and weak consumer spending.
British Airways said it's in merger talks with Australia's Qantas Airways.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Early Redemption
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to an upbeat open Tuesday, as equities look to rebound from the prior session's huge losses.
Nasdaq futures rallied 14 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures climbed 18 points and Dow futures gained 150 points.

Executives from the Big Three automakers are slated to submit their plans on how they'll use bailout money to restructure. Ford  (F), General Motors (GM) and Chrysler seek $25 billion to stave off bankruptcy. News reports say representatives from the auto makers won't fly in on their corporate jets this time. Shares of GM and Ford rose 10% and 9%, respectively, in the pre-market.
Data on November vehicle sales will be released throughout the day.

Many financials were indicated higher, though Goldman Sachs (GS) fell 4% in the pre-open. According to a news reports, Goldman will likely post a Q4 loss of $2 billion, or $5 a share. Thomson Reuters expects a loss of $1.06 a share. It would be the company's first quarterly loss since coming public in 1999.

On the retail front, Sears Holdings (SHLD) climbed 7% in the pre-market despite delivering a much wider-than-expected loss and withdrawing its profit outlook. For the third quarter, the operator of Kmart and its namesake stores lost $1.16 a share. Excluding charges, it lost 90 cents a share vs. views for a loss of 49 cents. Sales fell 8% to $10.66 billion, or below views. On the bright side, Sears will boost its stock buyback to $572 million from $500 million.

Staples (SPLS) reported Q3 earnings of 42 cents a share, unchanged from the prior year and a penny above views. Though ales gained 35% to $7 billion  the biggest increase in many quarters  that was below analysts' estimates. Shares rose 1% in the pre-open.

Elsewhere, General Electric (GE) said it expects Q4 earnings of 50 cents to 52 cents a share, at the low end of its prior forecast of 50 cents to 65 cents. Analysts had expected the conglomerate to earn 51 cents a share. Moody's affirmed GE's debt ratings shortly after the announcement. Shares gained 3% in the pre-market.

Crude oil rebounded a bit after sinking 10% Monday. The stock is trying to craft a right side to a monthlong base.Shire  (SHPGY) edged up 2% in healthy volume, preparing for its third test of resistance at its 50-day moving average this month.On the downside, United Therapeutics (UTHR) slipped 3%, leaving the biotech drug maker near its lows after a 35% sell-off Nov. 17.12:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Reach For Session Highs on Solid VolumeBY ALAN R. ELLIOTTFinancials and technology issues led as indexes pressed higher at noon.The NYSE composite broke out to a 3.6% gain. The S&P 500 and the NYSE composite pulsed 3.2% and 3% higher. The Dow pulled up 2.8%.Midcaps continued to head the gains, with the S&P 400 up 3.8%. All but two Dow components gained ground and nine-in-10 Nasdaq 100 stocks moved higher.Volume continued to improve from early, mixed levels, up 4% on the NYSE and 5% higher on the Nasdaq.Oil came under some pressure, slipping to a 45-month low below $48 a barrel.Stocks on the rebound included Clean Harbors (CLHB), which jumped 3%. The moved lifted shares back to near their 50-day moving average as the stock tries to flesh out a bottom to a three-month consolidation.Medical waste collection firm Stericycle (SRCL) popped for a 4% gain. That took back a portion of Monday's 11% drop, but left shares well below key levels of support.Strayer Education (STRA) hauled in a 5% advance. That returned shares to just below the 236.60 buy point cleared in last week's breakout from a cup-with-high-handle base.11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Retake Some Ground As Volume Rises BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT Stocks and commodities rebounded from Monday's sharp losses as U.S. automakers bargained with Congress for billions in taxpayer funding and as oil prices held largely unchanged.The NYSE composite led, up 2.9%. The Nasdaq composite held a 2.4% gain and the S&P 500 rode 2.4% higher. The Dow added 2%.Trading volume was up, slightly higher on the Nasdaq and the NYSE.Midcaps ran ahead of the crowd, the S&P 400 up 3.6% with Medicis Pharmaceuticals (MRX) and Williams Sonoma (WSM) posting the index's best gains.Oil rose by pennies, but held below $50 a barrel. Gold and most commodities moved higher. The dollar slipped vs. the euro but gained some ground against the yen.World Fuel Services (INT) jumped 6%, grabbing back most of Monday's 5% slide. The marine and aircraft fuels distributor broke above a 12-week cup-base Nov. 10. Tuesday's move lifted it back above the cup's 30.31 buy point.Technical school operator DeVry (DV) sparked 7% higher, also taking back its dip from Monday. That left shares just below the 58.87 buy point in an 11-week, cup-with-high handle base.On the downside, NCI (NCIT) tumbled 8%, compounding its 7% loss from Monday. That left the government IT services contractor just above its 50-day moving average, and 10% below a 26.95 buy point after a failed breakout attempt last week.Overseas, Monday's confirmation of global recession bit deep, driving Hong Kong's Hang Seng index down 5%. Property and financial issues led the decline. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 unraveled 6.4%.Things looked better in Europe and the U.K. as energy issues rebounded from Monday's sell-off. The DAX in Frankfurt, Germany, tacked on 1.7%. The CAC-40 in Paris showed a 0.9% gain and the FTSE 100 in London was 0.4% higher in afternoon trading.10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Open Higher, But Gains FadingBY VINCENT MAOStocks opened to the upside Tuesday, recouping a bit of Monday's hefty losses. But gains have waned since the opening bell and the Nasdaq nearly went negative.The NYSE composite was up 1.2%, the S&P 500 0.7%, the Nasdaq 0.5% and the Dow 0.4%.Volume was tracking sharply lower in the early going.Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) rose 14% following a stellar Q3 report. Late Monday, the online gaming firm said earnings climbed to 68 cents a share, up 55% from a year earlier and 10 cents above views. Sales grew 43% to $137 million, also above views. The company also announced investments in two leading gaming communities.Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) rallied 3% in fast trade. The retailer bounced back after sliding 7% in the prior session's sell-off. The stock remains just under a 40.58 buy point.3M  (MMM) lost 3% and fell further south of its 50-day moving average after Citigroup cut the diversified manufacturer to sell from hold on concerns about a strong dollar and weak consumer spending.British Airways said it's in merger talks with Australia's Qantas Airways.9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Early RedemptionBY VINCENT MAOStock futures pointed to an upbeat open Tuesday, as equities look to rebound from the prior session's huge losses.Nasdaq futures rallied 14 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures climbed 18 points and Dow futures gained 150 points.Executives from the Big Three automakers are slated to submit their plans on how they'll use bailout money to restructure. Ford  (F), General Motors (GM) and Chrysler seek $25 billion to stave off bankruptcy. News reports say representatives from the auto makers won't fly in on their corporate jets this time. Shares of GM and Ford rose 10% and 9%, respectively, in the pre-market.Data on November vehicle sales will be released throughout the day.Many financials were indicated higher, though Goldman Sachs (GS) fell 4% in the pre-open. According to a news reports, Goldman will likely post a Q4 loss of $2 billion, or $5 a share. Thomson Reuters expects a loss of $1.06 a share. It would be the company's first quarterly loss since coming public in 1999.On the retail front, Sears Holdings (SHLD) climbed 7% in the pre-market despite delivering a much wider-than-expected loss and withdrawing its profit outlook. For the third quarter, the operator of Kmart and its namesake stores lost $1.16 a share. Excluding charges, it lost 90 cents a share vs. views for a loss of 49 cents. Sales fell 8% to $10.66 billion, or below views. On the bright side, Sears will boost its stock buyback to $572 million from $500 million.Staples (SPLS) reported Q3 earnings of 42 cents a share, unchanged from the prior year and a penny above views. Though ales gained 35% to $7 billion  the biggest increase in many quarters  that was below analysts' estimates. Shares rose 1% in the pre-open.Elsewhere, General Electric (GE) said it expects Q4 earnings of 50 cents to 52 cents a share, at the low end of its prior forecast of 50 cents to 65 cents. Analysts had expected the conglomerate to earn 51 cents a share. Moody's affirmed GE's debt ratings shortly after the announcement. Shares gained 3% in the pre-market.Crude oil rebounded a bit after sinking 10% Monday. The January contract rose 48 cents to $49.76 a barrel.
5:15 p.m. Update: Markets on Friday neither extended nor contested Thursday's rally confirmation, notching a positive finish, but in lower volume.
Health care issues led throughout the day. The NYSE's Healthcare Index posted a 3% gain. The Nasdaq's biotech sector jumped 1.6% and its insurance component surged 2.6%.

According to preliminary calculations, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 indexes packed on 11% gains for the week. The NYSE composite plowed ahead 10% and the Dow threw down a 9% advance. Thursday's big volume gains turned the market from correction to confirmed rally. That signals buyers back into the market, but recommends only cautious buying until the rally proves its intent.

For Monday, analysts expect industrial production capacity utilization numbers from the Federal Reserve to show a fifth straight month of declines. The New York Fed is scheduled to release its Empire State Manufacturing Survey numbers for March. Both sets of data are due out before the market opens.

Keep an eye on Houston Wire & Cable (HWCC), Landry's Restaurants (LNY) and Sterling Construction (STRL), which plan to announce Q4 earnings prior to the market opening. China-based Internet content provider Sina (SINA) is on tap to report after hours.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Cap Strong Week By Closing Near Day's Highs
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed higher after fighting off midday weakness.
The Nasdaq rose 0.4% while the NYSE composite, S&P 500 and Dow were up 0.8% at the closing bell.
The indexes erased midday losses with an afternoon advance. The major averages closed near session highs.
Volume was lower as trading slowed in afternoon dealings.
A number of medical industry groups were among the day's best performers.
3:15 p.m. Update: Techs Lag, But Med Stocks Rock In Late Trade

5:15 p.m. Update: Markets on Friday neither extended nor contested Thursday's rally confirmation, notching a positive finish, but in lower volume.Health care issues led throughout the day. The NYSE's Healthcare Index posted a 3% gain. The major averages closed near session highs.Volume was lower as trading slowed in afternoon dealings.A number of medical industry groups were among the day's best performers.3:15 p.m. Update: Techs Lag, But Med Stocks Rock In Late Trade

5:15 p.m. Update: Markets remain under pressure, at least for now. But Thursday's strong win means the major indexes head into Friday with nice gains under their belts for the week. The Dow is at the low end, up 0.8%. The Nasdaq composite holds the high card, up 4.7% vs. last Friday's close.
The Nasdaq was the only one of the indexes to retake its 50-day line of support. Preliminary data show Thursday's Nasdaq volume at its highest levels since the Nov. 21 bottom.

After the close, Thoratec (THOR) slid 2% upon reporting Q4 earnings of 16 cents a share, 2 cents above consensus views. Revenue jumped 34% to $85.7 billion , also above analyst forecasts. It set out '09 EPS guidance of 70 to 76 cents a share vs. consensus views for 72 cents.

Medical waste collector Stericycle (SRCL) faltered 6% after just meeting Q4 EPS consensus of 45 cents, but falling short of revenue estimates. Stericycle has fallen since the market turned higher Nov. 21, living below its 10-week line since December.

Friday's light calendar includes Labor Department numbers on earnings, payroll, workweek and unemployment. Drugmaker Biogen (BIIB) headlines the earnings calendar, with some industry bellwethers like insurer Aon (AOC) and forest products heavyweight Weyerhauser (WI) also on the list.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close Higher As Volume Rises
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The major indexes closed sharply higher Thursday after erasing morning losses.
The Nasdaq jumped 2.1%, the S&P 500 and NYSE composite 1.6% and the Dow 1.3%.
Early readings showed that volume rose, solidifying the market's gains.

Sen. Christopher Dodd said some tweaking may be made to mark-to-market accounting rules for U.S. banks saddled with steep writedowns of bad assets. The news sent financials and much of the market higher.
3:15 p.m. Update: Transports Seize Gains, Possible Rule Change Grabs Attention
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes eased a bit further from their highs heading into the final hour of trading.

The Nasdaq composite continued to lead the market, up 1.8%. The NYSE composite showed a 1.4% gain. The Dow and S&P 500 held 1.3% advances. Transports bolted ahead of the general market with the Dow Transports index showing a 2.5% gain. JetBlue Airways (JBLU) and JB Hunt Transportation Services (JBHT) led the index.
Volume held sharply above Wednesday's action.

Part of the market's upside may have been a reaction to new reports that the Senate Banking Committee was discussing a possible modification to mark-to-market accounting rules for U.S. banks facing steep write-downs of troubled assets. Reports said the rule could possibly be changed while maintaining the underlying accounting standard. Committee chairman, Democrat Senator Christopher Dodd, had told reporters late Wednesday that at least one former bank regulator was pressing such an approach.

In stocks, Akamai Technologies (AKAM) spiked 18% higher after reporting adjusted Q4 EPS of 44 cents, well above consensus views of 40 cents. Revenue also grew more than expected, up 16% to $213 million against expectations for $207 million. The software applications developer and manager remains deep in a five-month correction.
On the downside, Family Dollar Stores (FDO) skidded 7% lower in heavy trading
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Trim Gains In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes pulled back in afternoon trading Thursday after putting in a big upside reversal earlier.
The Nasdaq pared a 2.5% gain to 1.7%. The NYSE composite also climbed 1.7%, the S&P 500 1.6% and the Dow 1.3%.
Turnover was tracking sharply higher across the board.
Despite gains in the major indexes, leaders up in volume were few.

Sepracor (SEPR) rallied 4% and regained its 200-day moving average. The stock had been trading under the line for nearly two years. Analysts see the biotech's earnings jumping 48% this year, up from 8% in 2008.

Bankrate (RATE) rose nearly 3% ahead of its earnings after the close. The financial data provider is slated to earn 34 cents a share on sales of $42 million. Earlier this morning, BanxCorp filed an antitrust complaint again Bankrate, accusing it of price fixing.

On the downside, Regal Beloit (RBC) gapped down and dropped 6% following its lackluster outlook. Late Wednesday, the motor maker reported a 6% drop in Q4 earnings, matching views. But it guided Q1 profit in the range of 38 cents to 46 cents a share vs. views of 68 cents. The stock was down nearly 13% at session lows.

Multi-Fineline Electronix (MFLX) erased early gains and shed 7% in heavy trading. Needham & Co. cut the electronics components maker to hold from buy. The company also reports earnings after the close. Analysts see profit falling 5% to 51 cents a share.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Surge To Fresh Highs In Broad Rally
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Markets muscled ahead in a broad advance carried on rising volume.
The Nasdaq composite set the pace, up 1.7%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 ran hot on its heels, adding 1.6% and 1.5%.
The Dow also picked up the tempo, rising 1.2% as American Express (AXP), Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Caterpillar (CAT) posted big-volume gains.
Volume powered up from weak, early levels to 25% higher on the Nasdaq and up 17% on the NYSE.
Small caps ran ahead of the pack, pushing the S&P 600 ahead 1.9%. SWS Group (SWS) and Carbo Ceramics (CRR) posted some of that index's best gains.
Crude oil remained little changed as commodities moved generally higher. Gold continued to top the list, up nearly $15 to above $916 an ounce. The dollar grabbed gains vs. both the euro and the yen.
Leading stocks jumped higher in droves.

Tower Group (TWGP) underwrote a 5% advance in better than double its average trade. The property and casualty insurer announced it had completed its $531 million acquisition of CastlePoint Holdings (CPHL). Shares are five weeks into a possible new base, after just clearing a four-month cup-with-handle.

Priceline (PCLN) rolled on 3%, heading toward a fourth day of gains ahead of its Feb. 9 Q4 earnings report. Analysts expect the online travel middleman's EPS growth to slow from solid double digits to 9%. But that trounced peer Expedia's (EXPE) outlook for a 19% backslide.
Airline Allegiant Travel (ALGT) turned and swiped a 4% gain after five straight down sessions.

The Las Vegas-based carrier reported late Wednesday its January traffic rose 9% vs. the year-ago period. That was a standout against the industry's general declines. The gain wasn't enough to alter the stock's seven-week slide, leaving it just above support at its 40-week moving average.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Extend Gains After Morning Reversal
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to push higher near the halfway point of Thursday's session.

The Nasdaq pulled a 180-degree turn after falling 1.3%. It was up 1.3%, regaining its 50-day moving average. Chips and high-profile issues Google (GOOG) and Apple (AAPL) boosted the tech-heavy index. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 rose 0.9% and 0.8%. The Dow lagged with a 0.5% gain.
Turnover was tracking sharply higher across the board.

Neutral Tandem (TNDM) gapped up, surged 15% and regained its 200-day moving average. Earlier this morning, the telecom service firm delivered Q4 earnings of 25 cents a share, up 317% and 6 cents above views. Sales surged 41% to $34.9 million, also above views. The firm guided full-year revenue in a range of $151 million to $158 million, vs. views for $151.06 million.

Watson Wyatt Worldwide (WW) gapped up and rallied 9% in heavy trade. Then the stock pulled back, nearly hitting its 200-day moving average. Before the open, the consulting firm beat views with a 13% rise in fiscal Q2 earnings. But it gave a mixed outlook. The company guided Q3 earnings and sales below analysts' estimates. Full-year revenue was also pegged below views. But it guided full-year profit above views.
AeroVironment (AVAV) reversed early losses and rallied 5% in fast trade. Late Wednesday, the company won a $41.7 million order for more unmanned aircraft systems and services.

On the downside, Dollar Tree (DLTR) gapped down, dived 16% and sliced its 200-day line. The retailer sold off despite saying that quarterly and full-year earnings were likely to be above the midpoint of previous guidance.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Reverse Early Losses, Climb To Positive Ground
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Some better-than-expected earnings and January same-store-sales numbers combined to haul indexes higher in late morning trading.

The Nasdaq composite led the turnaround, jumping 1.3% on the back of Nasdaq 100 components Akamai Technologies (AKAM), Ross Stores (ROST) and Urban Outfitters  (URBN). The NYSE composite and S&P 500 pulled 0.7% higher. Flower Foods  (FLO)topped the advancing issues priced above $10 on the S&P 500.
The Dow reversed out of a 1.1% loss to post a 0.3% gain.

The NYSE's industry sector indexes showed choppy, mixed trading. Most Nasdaq sectors ran higher, with banks and insurers dragging lower. Approximately 80% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD had moved lower in morning trading.

Volume was mixed, up 10% on the Nasdaq and a few clicks lower on the NYSE. The Commerce Department's factory orders data for December slipped a worse-than-expected 3.9%. The fifth straight month of declines was slower than November's 6.5% drop, but worse than consensus expectations for a 3.1% drop.

Crude oil futures traded down slightly, to just below $40 a barrel. Other commodities traded sharply mixed. Gold popped nearly $20 to above $922 an ounce. The dollar climbed against the euro and eased vs. the yen.

In stocks, Ross Stores (ROST) surged 7% in big volume. The discount retailer reported January same-store-sales fell 2%, less than the 2.9% drop expected by analysts. The stock is working to build the right side of a four-month base.

Solera Holdings  (SLH) also gained 7% in busy trading. The maker of software programs for auto insurers announced after the close Wednesday that its Q4 EPS jumped 34%, to 39 cents, well above analyst forecasts. Shares are just below a 24.49 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Earnings growth has slowed significantly since the first half of '08.
Overseas, markets in China closed narrowly mixed. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo posed a 1.1% decline.
Markets in Europe and the U.K. dropped after the European Central Bank held rates unchanged, and the Bank of England OK'd a half point rate cut to 1%, a historical low mark.
The CAC-40 in Paris dropped 2.4%. Frankfurt's DAX slumped 1.5%. The FTSE 100 in London backed off 1.8%
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Fall On Mixed Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks stumbled out of the gate Thursday on weak earnings, soft retail sales and a spike in jobless claims.
The S&P 500 dropped 1.2% and the Dow 1.1%. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite each lost 1%.
Volume was tracking mixed, with NYSE slightly lower but Nasdaq sharply higher.

Most retailers reported dismal January sales. Gap's (GPS) same-store sales tumbled 23% from a year earlier, though the company still upped its full-year profit outlook. Same-store sales at American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) declined 22% and 20%, respectively.
Department store operator J.C. Penney (JCP) posted a 16.4% dip in January same-store sales, while Dillard's (DDS) recorded a 12% decline.
Macy's (M) had a better go of it, reporting that same-store sales fell by a less-than-expected 4.5%. The company also raised its Q4 and full-year outlook.
Meanwhile, financials continued to suffer. Bank of America (BAC) tumbled 17%, while Wells Fargo (WFC) shed 11% and Citigroup (C) lost 8%.

Concur Technologies (CNQR) gapped down and tumbled nearly 16% after issuing warning of tough times ahead. Late Wednesday, the business software maker topped views with a 58% rise in fiscal Q1 earnings and a 19% gain in sales. But Chief Executive Steve Singh, citing a "challenging economic environment and eroding macro trends," said Concur continues to see "downward pressure on our near-term growth rates."

On the upside, Buckle (BKE) rose 8% after it reported a 14.7% increase in January same-store sales. Despite the economic slump, the teen apparel retailer has reported month after month of double-digit sales growth.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Set For Weak Start
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a lower open Thursday, following a mixed round of earnings and economic news.
Nasdaq futures dropped 23 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 8 points and Dow futures gave up 61 points.

In economic news, initial jobless claims increased by 35,000 to 626,000. That's the highest total in nearly 26 years and worse than forecasts for 592,000 claims. Continuing claims rose by 20,000 to a record 4.788 million.
On a brighter note, productivity rose 3.2% in the fourth quarter, more than tripling economists' estimates.
Data on December factory orders will be out at 10 a.m. EST.

In corporate news, Cisco Systems (CSCO) fell 4% in the pre-market following its disappointing outlook. Late Wednesday, the networking giant reported smaller-than-expected downturns in fiscal Q2 earnings and sales. But it projected a 15% to 20% drop in Q3 sales vs. views for an 11% decline.

Burger King (BKC) shed 6% in the pre-market after it missed earnings views and lowered its outlook. The fast-food chain's profit slipped to 33 cents a share in the second quarter, down from 36 cents a year earlier and 4 cents below estimates. Sales rose 3% to $634 million, also below views. Burger King cut its full-year profit guidance to a range of $1.44 to $1.49 a share from prior guidance of $1.54 to $1.59. Views are for $1.52.

On the upside, Visa (V) gained 8% in the pre-open following late Wednesday's fiscal Q1 earnings report. The credit card company posted a 37% rise in profit, beating views. But it missed sales estimates. Visa expects full-year 2009 profit growth of at least 20%, topping estimates of 16%.
Fellow credit card company MasterCard (MA) reported Q4 earnings of $1.84 a share, or 23 cents above views. It rose 4% in the pre-market.

Though a number of the nation's retailers delivered lackluster January same-store sales, Wal-Mart (WMT) was one of the few that bucked the trend. The world's largest retailer said its same-store sales rose 2.1%, excluding fuel. That beat views for a 1.1% increase. Wal-Mart will no longer provide monthly sales forecasts, but will do so on a quarterly basis. Shares climbed 2% in the pre-market.5:15 p.m. Update: Markets remain under pressure, at least for now. That was a standout against the industry's general declines. The gain wasn't enough to alter the stock's seven-week slide, leaving it just above support at its 40-week moving average.12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Extend Gains After Morning ReversalBY VINCENT MAOStocks continued to push higher near the halfway point of Thursday's session.The Nasdaq pulled a 180-degree turn after falling 1.3%. It was up 1.3%, regaining its 50-day moving average. Chips and high-profile issues Google (GOOG) and Apple (AAPL) boosted the tech-heavy index. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 rose 0.9% and 0.8%. The Dow lagged with a 0.5% gain.Turnover was tracking sharply higher across the board.Neutral Tandem (TNDM) gapped up, surged 15% and regained its 200-day moving average. Earlier this morning, the telecom service firm delivered Q4 earnings of 25 cents a share, up 317% and 6 cents above views. Sales surged 41% to $34.9 million, also above views. The firm guided full-year revenue in a range of $151 million to $158 million, vs. views for $151.06 million.Watson Wyatt Worldwide (WW) gapped up and rallied 9% in heavy trade. Then the stock pulled back, nearly hitting its 200-day moving average. Before the open, the consulting firm beat views with a 13% rise in fiscal Q2 earnings. But it gave a mixed outlook. The company guided Q3 earnings and sales below analysts' estimates. Full-year revenue was also pegged below views. But it guided full-year profit above views.AeroVironment (AVAV) reversed early losses and rallied 5% in fast trade. Late Wednesday, the company won a $41.7 million order for more unmanned aircraft systems and services.On the downside, Dollar Tree (DLTR) gapped down, dived 16% and sliced its 200-day line. The retailer sold off despite saying that quarterly and full-year earnings were likely to be above the midpoint of previous guidance.11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Reverse Early Losses, Climb To Positive GroundBY ALAN R. ELLIOTTSome better-than-expected earnings and January same-store-sales numbers combined to haul indexes higher in late morning trading.The Nasdaq composite led the turnaround, jumping 1.3% on the back of Nasdaq 100 components Akamai Technologies (AKAM), Ross Stores (ROST) and Urban Outfitters  (URBN). The NYSE composite and S&P 500 pulled 0.7% higher. Flower Foods  (FLO)topped the advancing issues priced above $10 on the S&P 500.The Dow reversed out of a 1.1% loss to post a 0.3% gain.The NYSE's industry sector indexes showed choppy, mixed trading. Most Nasdaq sectors ran higher, with banks and insurers dragging lower. Approximately 80% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD had moved lower in morning trading.Volume was mixed, up 10% on the Nasdaq and a few clicks lower on the NYSE. The Commerce Department's factory orders data for December slipped a worse-than-expected 3.9%. The fifth straight month of declines was slower than November's 6.5% drop, but worse than consensus expectations for a 3.1% drop.Crude oil futures traded down slightly, to just below $40 a barrel. Other commodities traded sharply mixed. Gold popped nearly $20 to above $922 an ounce. The dollar climbed against the euro and eased vs. the yen.In stocks, Ross Stores (ROST) surged 7% in big volume. The discount retailer reported January same-store-sales fell 2%, less than the 2.9% drop expected by analysts. The stock is working to build the right side of a four-month base.Solera Holdings  (SLH) also gained 7% in busy trading. The maker of software programs for auto insurers announced after the close Wednesday that its Q4 EPS jumped 34%, to 39 cents, well above analyst forecasts. Shares are just below a 24.49 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Earnings growth has slowed significantly since the first half of '08.Overseas, markets in China closed narrowly mixed. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo posed a 1.1% decline.Markets in Europe and the U.K. dropped after the European Central Bank held rates unchanged, and the Bank of England OK'd a half point rate cut to 1%, a historical low mark.The CAC-40 in Paris dropped 2.4%. Frankfurt's DAX slumped 1.5%. The FTSE 100 in London backed off 1.8%10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Fall On Mixed TradeBY VINCENT MAOStocks stumbled out of the gate Thursday on weak earnings, soft retail sales and a spike in jobless claims.The S&P 500 dropped 1.2% and the Dow 1.1%. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite each lost 1%.Volume was tracking mixed, with NYSE slightly lower but Nasdaq sharply higher.Most retailers reported dismal January sales. Gap's (GPS) same-store sales tumbled 23% from a year earlier, though the company still upped its full-year profit outlook. Same-store sales at American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) declined 22% and 20%, respectively.Department store operator J.C. Penney (JCP) posted a 16.4% dip in January same-store sales, while Dillard's (DDS) recorded a 12% decline.Macy's (M) had a better go of it, reporting that same-store sales fell by a less-than-expected 4.5%. The company also raised its Q4 and full-year outlook.Meanwhile, financials continued to suffer. Bank of America (BAC) tumbled 17%, while Wells Fargo (WFC) shed 11% and Citigroup (C) lost 8%.Concur Technologies (CNQR) gapped down and tumbled nearly 16% after issuing warning of tough times ahead. Late Wednesday, the business software maker topped views with a 58% rise in fiscal Q1 earnings and a 19% gain in sales. But Chief Executive Steve Singh, citing a "challenging economic environment and eroding macro trends," said Concur continues to see "downward pressure on our near-term growth rates."On the upside, Buckle (BKE) rose 8% after it reported a 14.7% increase in January same-store sales. Despite the economic slump, the teen apparel retailer has reported month after month of double-digit sales growth.9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Set For Weak StartBY VINCENT MAOStock futures signaled a lower open Thursday, following a mixed round of earnings and economic news.Nasdaq futures dropped 23 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 8 points and Dow futures gave up 61 points.In economic news, initial jobless claims increased by 35,000 to 626,000. That's the highest total in nearly 26 years and worse than forecasts for 592,000 claims. Continuing claims rose by 20,000 to a record 4.788 million.On a brighter note, productivity rose 3.2% in the fourth quarter, more than tripling economists' estimates.Data on December factory orders will be out at 10 a.m. EST.In corporate news, Cisco Systems (CSCO) fell 4% in the pre-market following its disappointing outlook. Late Wednesday, the networking giant reported smaller-than-expected downturns in fiscal Q2 earnings and sales. But it projected a 15% to 20% drop in Q3 sales vs. views for an 11% decline.Burger King (BKC) shed 6% in the pre-market after it missed earnings views and lowered its outlook. The fast-food chain's profit slipped to 33 cents a share in the second quarter, down from 36 cents a year earlier and 4 cents below estimates. Sales rose 3% to $634 million, also below views. Burger King cut its full-year profit guidance to a range of $1.44 to $1.49 a share from prior guidance of $1.54 to $1.59. Views are for $1.52.On the upside, Visa (V) gained 8% in the pre-open following late Wednesday's fiscal Q1 earnings report. The credit card company posted a 37% rise in profit, beating views. But it missed sales estimates. Visa expects full-year 2009 profit growth of at least 20%, topping estimates of 16%.Fellow credit card company MasterCard (MA) reported Q4 earnings of $1.84 a share, or 23 cents above views. It rose 4% in the pre-market.Though a number of the nation's retailers delivered lackluster January same-store sales, Wal-Mart (WMT) was one of the few that bucked the trend. The world's largest retailer said its same-store sales rose 2.1%, excluding fuel. That beat views for a 1.1% increase. Wal-Mart will no longer provide monthly sales forecasts, but will do so on a quarterly basis. Shares climbed 2% in the pre-market.
5:15 p.m. Update: Friday's steep early losses reversed, and a late-afternoon buying spree swept the market. Still, for the week, big losses were lodged.
The NYSE composite and Dow on Friday scored gains of 6.6% and 6.5%, respectively. The S&P 500 surged 6.3%. The Nasdaq, held back by a hard day in its biotech sector, rose 5.2% .
Preliminary data show volume rose 6% on the NYSE, but fell a tad on the Nasdaq.
For the week, the NYSE fell 9%, and Nasdaq lost 8.7%. The S&P 500 dropped 8.4% and the Dow slumped 5.3%.
Crude oil swung in a wide range Friday, but closed below $50 a barrel  down 13% for the week. The national average for gasoline prices slipped below $2 for the first time since March '05.

On Monday, preliminary GDP data is due out before the market opens. The National Association of Realtors will release new-home sales data at 10 a.m. EST. Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) and drug-store chain Walgreen (WAG) are scheduled to report Q3 results before the market opens.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Snap Back On Geithner Report
BY VINCENT MAO
Indexes screamed higher in the final hour of trade following reports that President-elect Barack Obama will tap New York Fed President Timothy Geithner as his Treasury secretary.
At the closing bell, the Dow rocketed 6.5%, with 28 of 30 components finishing higher. The blue chip index also regained the 8000 level. The NYSE composite surged 6.3%, S&P 500 6% and Nasdaq 4.3%.
Volume rose slightly on the NYSE and fell a bit on the Nasdaq. Despite the gains, breadth wasn't impressive. Advancers beat decliners by less than 2-to-1 on the NYSE and about 8-to-5 on the Nasdaq.

According to NBC, Obama will formally name Geithner as his top financial official on Monday. Geithner served as a Clinton Treasury official under Bob Rubin and Larry Summers. Also ex-Energy Secretary and current New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson will be tapped as Commerce secretary.
Salesforce.com (CRM) fell 3% after gaining nearly 13% at the open.
Dell (DELL) also gave up good gains, finishing down 5%.
Citigroup (C) bounced back from a 35% drop, finishing down 20%.
Crude oil settled at $49.93 a barrel, up 51 cents. But on the week, the commodity slumped 13%.
A more complete roundup will be available in the 5:15 p.m. market update.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Seesaw In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Rebound efforts waned, leaving the major stock indexes narrowly mixed in a back-and-forth session late Friday.
The Dow and NYSE composite gained 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. The Nasdaq fell 0.3%, and the S&P 500 was flat.
Turnover was now tracking slightly higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq. Still, decliners beat advancers by about 2-to-1 on both exchanges.
Dell (DELL) stumbled 8% to an 11-year low. The computer maker had been up nearly 7% after it topped views late Thursday.
Celgene (CELG) dropped 9%, nearing a 52-week trough. The biotech slumped for the sixth straight session after recently running into resistance at its 50-day moving average.
PetMed Express (PETS) shed 6% in fast trade and neared its 50-day line.
On the upside, gold issues shined. December gold settled at $791.80 an ounce, up $43.10, or 6%. It briefly topped $800.
Barrick Gold (ABX) surged 27%, and Agnico Eagle Mines (AEM) rallied 19%.
2:15 p.m. Update: Update: Indexes Pull Back Into Holding Pattern
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes circled around the break-even mark in midafternoon trading, as energy stocks continued to lead and the financial and medical sectors struggled.
The NYSE composite pulled back from a 3.7% jump in early trading to a 0.6% gain. The Nasdaq gave up a 2.6% advance to slip 0.4% lower. The Dow and S&P 500 were flat.
Volume ebbed, tracking lower on both major exchanges. Declining issues led advancers by 3-to-2 on the NYSE and by about 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Exxon Mobil (XOM) jumped 4% in moderate trading. Chevron (CVX)added 2%. Both stocks saw steep drops Thursday.
On the downside, Huron Consulting (HURN) dropped 6% in fast trade. The corporate consultant was struggling to pierce resistance at its 50-day moving average.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Push Higher As Volume Turns Mixed
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Energy issues continued leading the market in early afternoon trading, as indexes remained higher. Health care stocks lagged, however.
The NYSE composite climbed 2.1%, followed by the Dow's 1.7% gain, the S&P 500's 1.5% and a 1.1% rise on the Nasdaq.
Small caps were under pressure, with the S&P 600 down 0.3%.
Volume was mixed: 6% above Thursday's strong levels on the NYSE, but down 7% on the Nasdaq. That decline came despite the expiration of options today.
Nasdaq 100 component Amgen  (AMGN) gapped up and added 6% after reporting it received a favorable review from a European advisory committee regarding its blood-clotting drug Nplate.
But other biotechs took a beating.
Gen-Probe (GPRO) crumbled 12%. Techne (TECH) dove 6%. Celgene (CELG) tanked at the opening, but pared its loss to 5% in afternoon trading.
World Fuel Services  (INT) climbed 11%, erasing some of its 17% dive on Thursday.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Shave Off Early Red
BY VINCENT MAO
After a quick dip into the red, stocks bounced back and were nearing morning highs.
Volume continued to track higher on the NYSE, but the pace has slowed dramatically. Nasdaq volume is now tracking lower, despite options expiration.

Citigroup (C) turned a 17% gain into a 15% loss and hit a 16-year low. According to CNBC, Citi Chief Executive Vikrum Pandit says he wants to keep the company together and doesn't want to spin off its Smith Barney unit.
Wells Fargo (WFC) reversed early gains, sliding 9% to a seven-year low.
Meanwhile, Salesforce.com (CRM) turned tail and fell 3%. The software maker was up nearly 14% intraday after its latest quarterly report and two upgrades.
Leaders continued to falter. Genoptix (GXDX) tumbled 10% and sliced its 200-day moving average. The laboratory services provider opened higher but quickly turned negative.
January crude oil reversed gains and slipped 37 cents to $49.05 a barrel. Energy issues held on to decent gains. World Fuel Services (INT) jumped 6%; Exxon Mobil (XOM) climbed 3%.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Retract Into Mixed Territory In Firm Volume
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes pared early gains and slipped into mixed territory as financial sectors showed mixed trading and medical stocks saw some heavy selling.
The NYSE composite held a 1% gain, while the Nasdaq composite dribbled 0.2% lower. The Dow strained to hold its 0.1% gain and the S&P 500 rested at the break-even mark.
The NYSE's Energy Index powered 3.2% higher. Health care was the loss leader, with a 1.5% decline.

Chevron (CVX), Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Microsoft (MSFT) led the Dow's upside. Citigroup (C) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) provided the main drag. Autodesk (ADSK), Stericycle (SRCL) and Celgene (CELG) notched some of the Nasdaq 100's heftiest losses.
Volume ran well above Thursday's strong levels, 25% higher on the NYSE and 5% on the Nasdaq.
Energy issues led much of the upside action.

EOG Resources (EOG) pulsed 5% higher. The natural gas producer is struggling to regain its 10-week line after a sharp, two-day drop. The sell-off followed a downgrade to market perform by Howard Weil on Tuesday.

Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) added 5% in firm volume as commodities futures gained. The agricultural commodities powerhouse slipped back to test support at its 10-week moving average after a three-week climb.

On the downside, Gen-Probe (GPRO) gapped down to a 13% loss. Needham & Co. initiated coverage Thursday with a hold rating. But the disease diagnostic and blood-screening products maker has been falling since Nov. 11, and is down 25% so far this week.
Commodities in general gained while oil hovered just below the $50 a barrel mark. Natural gas and gold perked up 2%. The dollar slipped vs. the euro, but both currencies gained against the yen.
Overseas markets in Asia closed generally higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index added 2.9%. The Shanghai composite grudged out a 0.7% loss. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan sprung 2.7%.

Indexes traded squarely lower as Europe and the U.K. moved into afternoon trading. The CAC-40 in Paris posted a 2% decline. Frankfurt's DAX subtracted 1.2%. The FTSE 100 in London erased mild early gains to slip 1.1%.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Pull Back From Strong Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks charged out of the gate early Friday but have since pared a chunk of gains.
The NYSE composite was up 2%, the Nasdaq 1.4%, the S&P 500 1.2% and the Dow 0.9%.
Volume tracked vastly higher across the board due to options expiration.
Commodity-related issues such as steel, metal and energy were among the best performers.
Research In Motion (RIMM) moved up 6% in fast trade. The company's BlackBerry Storm smart phone goes on sale today.
Apple (AAPL), which makes the rival iPhone, rose 4% as it bounced back from a near two-year low.

On the downside, Autodesk (ADSK) gapped down and tumbled 18% to a four-year low following a disappointing outlook. Late Thursday, the design software maker reported Q3 earnings and sales above views but guided Q4 results well below estimates. This morning, two brokers downgraded the stock.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Headed For Upbeat Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures surged early Friday, pointing to a sharply higher open as Wall Street looks to rebound from its worst two-day slide in years.
Nasdaq futures rallied 21 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures gained 18 points and Dow futures climbed 149 points.

Citigroup (C) climbed 10% in the pre-market after a media report said the bank will hold a meeting to discuss ways to prop up its sliding stock price. This may include selling pieces of or the entire company. This week alone, shares plunged 50%.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) filed to sell an undisclosed amount of mixed securities, and its Washington Mutual unit will cut 1,600 jobs in the San Francisco area. JPMorgan also reportedly will cut 10% of its investment banking staff. The firm has remained profitable during the credit crisis, but earnings growth has waned four quarters in a row. Analysts expect that trend to continue the next two quarters. Shares rose 2% in the pre-open.
Citing global economic weakness, Bank of New York Mellon (BNY) will slash 1,800 jobs, or about 4% of its staff.
Other financials were indicated higher. Morgan Stanley (MS) gained 7% in the pre-open, Bank of America (BAC) 4% and Goldman Sachs (GS) 3%.

Elsewhere, Dell (DELL) rallied 6% in the pre-market after late Thursday's report that Q3 earnings came in above views. Still, Friedman, Billings Ramsey cut Dell shares to market perform from outperform this morning.

Salesforce.com (CRM) surged 12% following Thursday night's stellar third-quarter results. Earlier today, Roth Capital upgraded the software firm to buy from hold. Robert W. Baird raised shares to outperform from neutral.
Crude oil bounced back from a three-year low. The now front-month January contract gained $1.33 to $50.75 a barrel.
No economic reports are on tap today.
